Alice's goal for her novels is to fill a gap in children's fiction. She believes many books for teenagers today focus on negative experiences or are complete fantasy, like Harry Potter. Her books are different. Alice always tried to teach English and History together, like teaching about ancient Greece with the novel "Tale of Troy," and she loves seeing children go from being bored to interested. She sees her writing as an extension of teaching.

Alice was inspired to write her first novel because there was a gap in the market and because her two sons were leaving home. Her head teacher suggested she take a creative writing course, which surprised her. She didn't want to spend her summer on a course she thought unnecessary. Before the course, she had to send her best piece of fiction, which she wrote quickly about a Roman couple and their baby. The course students liked her story and suggested she publish it. With only school report cards as proof of her writing skills, she asked for a year off to write her first novel. Her husband, Zachary Leader, a critic and editor, helped her edit the novel. Alice says they complement each other; he helps improve her writing by suggesting changes, while she likes to add more scenes.

To raise money for charity, a newspaper and a TV company challenged brothers Jonny and Alistair Brownlee, who are champion triathletes, to compete in a special race. The race would be between a man and a car, and also between the two brothers. In the wild and hilly Yorkshire Dales in northern England, Jonny would drive a car on the roads, while his younger brother Ali would ride a mountain bike across the countryside. 

Jonny was excited about the race as he stood at the start line. He said, "I’ve never done anything like this before; it’s exciting! These roads have beautiful views, and it’s very cold right now, so I’ll be warm in the car." Alistair was also eager to start. Unlike Jonny, who wore jeans and a sweatshirt, Alistair was dressed in full winter cycling gear. He joked, "I’ve seen Jonny drive before, so I’m not sure he’ll even make it. I might just stop for a cup of tea halfway up."

The race began at the beautiful Semerwater lake in Wensleydale and was to end at Yorkshire’s highest road, Fleet Moss, which is 350 meters up. This might not be a problem for the car, but Alistair had a tough start with a steep 25 percent incline. After a quick handshake, they were off. Alistair quickly rode his bike up the hill and across the countryside to Fleet Moss, while Jonny got into the car and started driving. They would only see each other again at the finish line. The question was, who would get there first?

Jonny’s confidence was quickly tested. Just 15 seconds into the drive, he faced his first problem: a giant tractor was blocking the road. "Welcome to Yorkshire," he joked to the cameraman in his car. "If Alistair beats me, it’s because of this farmer!" After a tense moment, Jonny got past the tractor and continued driving into the morning mist.

Meanwhile, Alistair was struggling with the steep hill. Just a couple of miles in, he had to get off his bike and carry it up the hill, past walls and over fences. Sheep watched him as he kept a steady pace, carrying his bike on his shoulders. Finally, he reached the top. On the other side, the ground was open, and with the sun shining, he could show his skills. He put his head down, pedaled hard, and picked up speed.

In the car, Jonny faced another local challenge. The roads in this part of Yorkshire are very old and not made for fast driving. Jonny had to carefully drive through narrow corners and a stream on the road. Once he was past the last village, he raced straight to the finish line. Neither brother knew how close the other was. As Jonny sped towards Fleet Moss, Alistair was racing across his last field and back onto the road, approaching the finish from the other side. He pedaled hard and then braked as he reached the line. 

Alistair looked up and asked the crowd, "Is he here?" When they said no, he raised his arms in victory. Minutes later, Jonny arrived in the car. "Well done," Jonny said, feeling disappointed. "I’m gutted."

Playing on Centre Court at Wimbledon is a unique experience because of the silence. When you bounce the ball on the soft grass, you can hear the echo of your shots. The well-kept grass, the history, the old stadium, the players in white, and the respectful crowds make you feel separated from the outside world. This quiet helps me focus on my game. During a match, I try hard to concentrate only on the game and the point I’m playing. The silence is broken by noise when a point ends: applause, cheers, and people shouting your name. I hear them, but it feels distant. I don’t notice the fifteen thousand people watching every move my opponent and I make. I am so focused that I forget millions are watching me play Roger Federer in the 2008 Wimbledon final – the biggest match of my life. I always dreamed of playing at Wimbledon. My uncle Toni, who has been my coach all my life, taught me that this was the most important tournament. By age 14, I was telling my friends I would play there one day and win. Before 2008, I played and lost twice, both times against Federer – in the final the year before and the year before that. Losing in 2006 wasn’t too hard. I was just happy to have made it that far at age twenty. Federer beat me easily because I didn’t believe in myself enough. But losing in 2007 was devastating. I knew I could have done better, and it wasn’t my skills that failed me, but my mindset. I cried for half an hour in the dressing room. Losing is always painful, but it’s worse when you had a chance and lost it. Toni, who is a tough coach, usually doesn’t comfort me, even when I win. But seeing how upset I was, he told me not to cry and that there would be more chances. I told him he didn’t understand, that this might have been my last chance to win. I know a professional athlete’s career is short, and I want to make the most of it. Every moment is important, but some are more important than others, and I missed a big one in 2007. Toni couldn’t make me feel better, but he was right in the end. I got another chance. In 2008, I was back in the final. I was confident I had learned from my defeat a year earlier, and this time my mindset would be strong. The best sign that I was ready was my belief that I would win. The night before the final, at dinner with family and friends, we didn’t talk about the match. I didn’t tell them not to, but they knew I was already thinking about the match in my mind. From then until the match started, that space in my mind was mine alone.

A young and idealistic Englishwoman named Jane Goodall arrived in Africa in April 1957. In one of her first letters home, she wrote, "I am living in the Africa I have always longed for, always felt stirring in my blood." Jane spent most of her life in Africa and became known as a citizen, journalist, scientist, activist, and environmentalist. In 1963, Britain's National Geographical Society helped make her famous by creating articles and TV documentaries about her research on chimpanzees. Her fame grew with her own writing, including award-winning children's books and the 1971 bestseller "In the Shadow of Man," which has been translated into 47 languages.

Jane Goodall is one of the most celebrated female scientists of the 20th century, possibly second only to Marie Curie. However, her fame sometimes hides her real achievements. Many articles and books about her life focus on her as an adventurous girl, a privileged woman who dreamed of living with wild animals, or a determined feminist. These images can undervalue her true work. Based on how often her research is referenced by other scientists, the success of her students, and the data she collected over 40 years, Jane Goodall should be seen as a leading pioneer in her field and the world's top zoologist.

Her main achievement is simple: she helped us understand the social and emotional lives of chimpanzees. Before her work, people misunderstood the dangers of wild chimpanzees. No one knew they ate meat or used tools. We didn't realize they have emotions similar to humans or that their social systems are like ours. We also didn't know that chimpanzee communities have different cultural traditions. Her book, "The Chimpanzees of Gombe" (1986), is the most important work in this area and is like an encyclopedia for chimpanzee research. Her long-term study in Gombe, Nigeria, is considered one of the great scientific achievements of the Western world. Jane Goodall changed how we study animals and, because chimpanzees are our closest relatives, she also changed how we think about ourselves.

Even as a child, Jane showed signs of the person she would become. When she was five years old, in the autumn of 1939, she disappeared one day. The police and neighbors searched for her. As it got dark, she suddenly reappeared with straw in her hair and clothes. Her mother asked where she had been. Jane explained that she wanted to know how hens lay eggs, so she hid in a henhouse for five hours to watch. This curiosity can be seen as the start of her career as a biologist.

During our first hour-long conversation, Shirley Ford talks to me using different voices. She sounds like a cheeky 8-year-old boy, the boy’s tired mother, a funny old Scottish woman, and a very fast-talking alien. Her voices are familiar to people who watch children’s TV and cartoons, and to those who have seen computer programs about health and safety. ‘I just did a voiceover about back injuries,’ she says, ‘so I had to quickly learn how to say many medical terms.’ Shirley explains what it takes to do voiceovers. ‘Many actors, even famous ones, think they can do funny voices, and many probably can,’ she says. ‘But there’s more to it. You have to make the script come alive for an audience who can’t see you. You wouldn’t believe how many famous people want to do voiceover work. Producers invite them to auditions for publicity, but often they don’t get the parts because they are used to acting with their whole bodies.’

After school, Shirley took a drama course, planning a normal acting career. During the course, she sometimes sang jingles for TV ads. ‘One day,’ she says, ‘the man who ran the recording studio suggested I try out for the part of a rabbit in a cartoon. It seemed silly – I hadn’t studied drama to play rabbits – but I tried it for fun and, amazingly, got a major part.’ Shirley realized she could do voices and that voiceover work might be her path. ‘Things just happened for me,’ she says. ‘In my second film, I was lucky to play the main character – and her brother and mother.’

Adult female actors often provide voices for small boys and girls. Their voices are lighter than male actors, and hiring child performers involves complex procedures and many forms, which production companies on tight schedules prefer to avoid. Shirley has learned to create the right sounds from the back of her throat, and to avoid always sounding like the same child, she collects new voices by watching children’s TV. Cartoons are the highlight of a job that includes everything from educational videos to vacuum cleaner ads. ‘Those are hard because you have to sound excited about something you don’t care about, but my years in this profession help,’ she says. ‘They’ve taught me that the trick is to smile while you're talking – that makes your voice sound bright and happy. When I have days doing animation work, it feels like a holiday; interacting with other actors makes a big difference.’

The competition for work is tough, and a good showreel – a recording showing what the artist can do – is essential. ‘It’s definitely worth investing in a strong showreel,’ Shirley says. ‘There are agencies that specialize in helping voiceover artists create them.’ She claims she got to where she is – near the top of her profession – through persistence as much as natural talent. ‘Whether it’s making your showreel and taking it to all the film and TV companies, advertising agencies, and recording studios, or simply practicing your voices, it’s all about setting goals and not giving up.’

For anyone thinking about a career in voiceovers, Shirley recommends attending ‘specialist workshops – they cover all types of voiceover.’ She also believes a passion for human sound is important, describing herself as obsessed with voices and, in a way, becoming the characters she performs. ‘If I’ve been in the studio doing a particular kind of American voice, for example, it can take over me and I’ll be speaking like that for hours, maybe even days afterwards,’ she says. ‘My children have grown up used to their mum talking in completely different voices.’

People often ask me how I became a cartoonist. This makes sense because cartooning is a job many kids dream about, like being a race car driver. However, most people eventually choose more realistic jobs, like becoming a tax lawyer or making car parts. The idea of making a living by drawing doodles, like those in school notebooks, seems silly. But some people do it. People become cartoonists in different ways, but most have wanted to do it for a long time. 

For me, I had a typical cartoonist's childhood. I loved comic strips, contributed to school publications, and was known as 'the kid who draws.' I studied graphic design in college and, after graduating, showed my illustrations to different companies. I was lucky to find someone at a newspaper who needed political cartoons about local issues. I drew some ideas, they bought them, and in a few months, I was making enough money to support myself.

To become a cartoonist, you don't need a university degree, much money, or even great drawing skills. You just need your brain, your hand, and something to draw with. But if it were that easy, there would be as many cartoonists as teachers. The technical skills needed are not high, but it's still a tough job. You shouldn't try to become a cartoonist unless you feel you can't do anything else. It's easier to get a regular job that pays the rent and leaves time for family and hobbies.

The more skills you have, the better your chances of making a living with your art. I've done political cartoons, comic strips, and comic books. I've also been a writer, a caricaturist, and sometimes a designer. I don't turn down any work because you can learn a lot from jobs you don't really want to do. It also helps to be smart, well-read, and curious about everything.

What about the business side of being a cartoonist? There was a time when many cartoonists could find regular jobs at newspapers and magazines. But those days are almost over. Today, cartooning is more like running your own business. You have to create the work and sell it. The better you are at this, the more successful you'll be. I've seen cartoonists with average talent but great business skills do better than artistic geniuses who lack business sense.

It's surprising how many people are afraid someone will steal their ideas, even if they've never sold a cartoon. Some are so worried they won't let others see their work. To protect your work legally, just draw a small 'c' for 'copyright,' put a circle around it, and write your name and the date next to it. But honestly, it's more likely that no one will be interested in your work. If someone does steal a cartoon and it becomes popular online, it might actually be a lucky break!

Twenty years ago, I was moving to a new house and decided to get rid of some things. One of those things was an electric guitar my dad gave me for my 16th birthday. It was a sleek, black guitar made in Japan. I usually hate throwing things away, so why did I want to throw this away? I took it to the rubbish dump and was about to throw it on a pile of trash when a young man came up to me, looking confused. He asked, "You’re not just going to throw that away, are you?" I said I was, but I already felt a bit of regret. He asked if he could have it, and I said yes. We went our separate ways. 

In the years that followed, I often felt sad about what I had done. Then, a few months ago, I got an email that changed my life. It reminded me of a story about a man who lost his wedding ring in the ocean and found it years later in a fish he was eating. The email was from someone I didn’t know, a guitar dealer and restorer named Keith Rushton. He told me, "I’ve got your electric guitar." The guitar had been bought and sold several times since I gave it away. Keith found a name-and-address label on the back. He knew it was probably old, but he used my name to find me online. He contacted me through the newspaper I work for and offered to sell it back to me. I almost cried. I would have paid anything, but his price was fair. I had forgotten my dad’s habit of putting name-and-address stickers on everything, including my guitar. My dad would have laughed at this strange story!

My parents wanted me to learn the classical guitar in the 1970s when classical guitarists were popular. I loved its calming and gentle sound, which was nice for beginners. But I didn’t make much progress, so I switched to the electric guitar, playing simple music. It was also the time of punk music, where you didn’t need to play well to be a rock star. When I took my old guitar out of the box Keith sent me, I remembered my birthday in 1978 when my parents gave it to me. Holding it again, it felt smooth and smaller than I remembered. I stood up and put a strap over my shoulder because the electric guitar is meant to be played standing. My fingers remembered where to go. I couldn’t draw the chords, but my hands knew them. My fingertips felt the pain of pressing the strings to play a chord. The electric guitar is not really for playing alone. Now that I’m learning it again, I think I’ll need to form a band. My son is learning the saxophone; maybe I can play with him. Or maybe there are others my age with a similar story. Maybe we could call ourselves ‘The Regainers’!

There has been a lot of discussion about sleep recently. When I wrote the book "Insomniac," about people who can't sleep, I felt like I was the only one talking about how dangerous not getting enough sleep can be. Lack of sleep affects our minds, bodies, and moods. People who have trouble sleeping know how important sleep is for our mental, physical, and social health. It's good that sleep is finally getting the attention it deserves. But what about dreams? I haven't heard much about them in these discussions. We often lose dreams when we wake up early, missing the last hour or two of sleep. This is usually the REM stage, or 'Rapid Eye Movement,' which is when we dream the most. Our most vivid and emotional dreams happen during REM, just before we wake up. A good sleeper spends about a quarter of their sleep in REM, so someone who lives 90 years will spend six or seven years dreaming. When researchers stop people from having REM sleep, they have more intense REM sleep the next night to make up for it. This suggests that dreams are important. When REM was discovered in 1953, many agreed with psychologist Sigmund Freud, who thought that understanding dreams was the best way to understand our minds. But it wasn't that simple. Later research on the brain didn't support this idea, and the study of dreams shifted to their physical origins. Currently, there is little agreement among dream researchers, says Harvard University sleep scientist Robert Stickgold. Dreams are important. At a meeting of the Associated Professional Sleep Society, P.F. Pagel from the University of Colorado Medical School talked about a study showing that actors, writers, and directors remember and use their dreams better than other people. He concluded that people who are interested in creativity use their dreams more. It makes sense that filmmakers have a strong connection with their dreams because films are very dream-like. But I wondered, are only artistic people using their dreams? Don't teachers, software designers, and politicians also need to think creatively? Dreams, according to Stickgold, help us connect things in new and surprising ways, using knowledge from the past and present to find new ideas. Dreams might help us see new patterns and create new combinations that break our usual ways of thinking. For example, Stickgold found that when people are woken up from REM sleep and asked to respond to a word, their answers are more original than when woken from other sleep stages. They ignore the obvious and connect things in unexpected ways. This is what creativity is, says Stickgold. I write better after intense dreams. Even a troubling dream, even one you can barely remember, seems to help with thinking. On those days, words and images come so quickly that I can barely type fast enough. I don't know how it works, but it does. But creativity isn't just for writers or artists. We live in a complex world, and we all need our brains to work well. We need to think creatively and flexibly in our relationships with colleagues, co-workers, family, and friends. This is why we need to dream.

Susie Ray moved from London to a small coastal town in south-west England twenty years ago. In her studio, which has a beautiful view of the sea, you can see empty frames on the walls and photos of her two daughters. Susie is a leading artist in the copyist art movement, meaning she can recreate famous paintings from the past, like those by Caravaggio or impressionist artists, with great skill. However, she doesn't keep any of her own work because they are sold as soon as she finishes them. 

Susie is very popular and has been a copyist artist for 30 years, painting works by famous artists like Renoir, Monet, and Van Gogh. Her copies are so accurate that even art experts sometimes think they are the originals. While the original paintings are worth millions, Susie's reproductions sell for between a few hundred pounds and £12,000, depending on how much time she spends on them. She has many clients, including galleries and private collectors, but she doesn't usually reveal their names. Some collectors buy her copies to show off, while others use them to save on insurance by keeping the original in a safe place.

Susie is honest about her work. She tries to make her reproductions look as real as possible and signs her name on the back of the canvas. Selling a copy as an original is illegal, and although some people do it, Susie has never been tempted because it could cause problems. She isn't rich and has had tough times, but her situation is better now, and she doesn't want to risk her reputation.

Before becoming a copyist, Susie worked as an illustrator for a botanical garden after finishing her art degree. She didn't earn much, but it taught her to be precise and gave her a love for plants. She has no regrets about that time, but she's happy to have found a more financially rewarding career. When young artists ask for advice, Susie tells them to learn to draw accurately and study hard. Her skills allow her to create anything from plant drawings to perfect copies of old masterpieces, but she now focuses on French impressionists like Manet, Cezanne, and Degas.

Some people think modern art is easy, but Susie disagrees. She says impressionists painted quickly but were also very careful, which is hard to do well. Although Susie is very talented, she doesn't create her own original art. She has tried, like painting fishing nets, but they ended up looking like photographs. Susie is a perfectionist and is happy with her work as a copyist, which she has trained for many years to do well.

During her racing days, Ellen MacArthur loved the sea more than anything, except maybe being the fastest on it. She was obsessed with sailing since she was a child. She felt a special connection with the boats that took her around the world. They worked together as one. When she was back on land, everyday life seemed unimportant, and people always wanted to know about the race. She quickly wanted to return to the ocean, challenging herself against nature, even in dangerous places. After she came second in the Vendée Globe, a solo round-the-world race, she showed me her boat, Kingfisher. It was her home and workplace for 94 days. She explained how she planned everything carefully, even counting how many rolls of kitchen paper she needed. Preparation was crucial, she said. She proudly showed her supplies of freeze-dried food, a small gas stove, and bags of medical items. Her boat was her world, and she took care of it because her life depended on it.

Now, Ellen sees the world like a boat: small, beautiful, and fragile, with limited resources. Her perspective changed during a trip to South Georgia, a remote island in the South Atlantic, where she helped with a bird survey. She realized things she hadn't thought about before. Seeing abandoned whaling stations made her think about how humans take what they want and move on. When I visited Ellen’s office, she had just finished a conference call. She explained why we need to act now to save the planet. "No one is making more coal, oil, or gas. They are precious resources we have only once. We need to find ways not to use them up," she said. At first, her message was to use less, but then she started focusing on re-using. She talked passionately about things like reusable industrial carpet tiles. For the last three years, she has visited factories, mines, and power stations, speaking to governments and businesses about our dependence on non-renewable resources. "I will never be an expert," she said, "but I love learning. I couldn’t ignore the current situation. Sailing seemed selfish compared to this. This is about finding how my voice can help. It really matters."

Ellen also started the Ellen MacArthur Foundation, a charity that works with businesses and education to help young people think about and design a sustainable future. "I do miss the adventure of being at sea," she said. "It’s what makes me who I am. You feel connected to everything around you. You don’t have time to feel lonely. You focus on the record, on practical things, on survival. My new message isn’t as simple as saying, 'I’m going to be the fastest person around the world.' I may have been the fastest, but this is more important than anything I’ve ever done."

Jordan Romero is 13 years old and wants to be the youngest person to climb Mount Everest. If he succeeds, he could become a very famous teenager. Many young people spend a lot of time on computers and video games, so Jordan hopes to encourage them to go outside and try new challenges. His climbing team includes his father, Paul, and his mother, Karen. They call themselves 'Team Romero.' Climbing Everest is just one of their goals. If Jordan climbs Everest and Vinson Massif in Antarctica, he will be the youngest person to climb the Seven Summits, which are the highest mountains on each continent. Not many people do this before they turn thirty. Jordan has already climbed five of these mountains and might finish before he turns 20.

I talked to some experienced Everest climbers, and none of them thought it was a good idea for a 13-year-old to climb the world's highest mountain. They agreed that a young climber might be physically strong enough, but they were not sure if a teenager would be emotionally ready. They also doubted that a young person could have enough experience to make safe decisions while climbing. The Romeros have heard these opinions before. Paul says, 'I know people criticize us, but I can't focus on that – we have a lot to do. We think about the risks, but we trust our experience as climbers. Watching Jordan grow stronger gives me confidence. He is becoming mature.'

I also wonder why Jordan wants to do this. Is it because his father loves adventure too much? Paul says, 'This isn't about me trying to be famous through my son. At first, Jordan thought about doing this later in life, but we decided, why not now? We talk to him often to make sure he still wants to do it.' When I ask Jordan what he enjoys about the challenge, he says, 'I just focus on reaching my goal.'

In the past, not many people cared about being the youngest or fastest to climb a mountain or sail an ocean. Today, every adventure is shared online, and every climb becomes a chance to set a record. The more exciting the record, the more people are interested. This gives Jordan a problem. People might say that focusing on records takes away the fun, but if Jordan wants to inspire others, he has to share his story with the media. This means blogging, taking photos, and giving interviews. He needs to do something amazing, like climbing Everest. Paul says, 'If Jordan decides he wants to stop climbing and play basketball instead, we'll stop this project and go to the gym.'

When you see a teenager with an MP3 player, it's likely they aren't listening to classical music. Most people can name many pop groups, but if you ask my friends about Brahms, they probably won't know who he is. I'm studying music at university, but even my classmates don't know much about classical music. If you don't know the composers, you probably don't own their music. The numbers are discouraging for classical music fans. Only 3% of concert tickets sold last year were for classical music, and the average classical album sells only 300 copies. I find that surprising. So, why is there less interest in classical music, which has been around for centuries? Older people often blame TV and video games, but I don't think that's the reason. The truth is, classical music doesn't attract most people, especially teenagers, who are the main buyers of music and concert tickets. I know some teenagers who love classical concerts, but they are few. Even though I play in an orchestra, I'm not a big classical music fan. I like many music styles, but my classical music collection is probably close to that 3% figure. Why don't teenagers like classical music? First, the pace and rhythm of classical music, with its many mood changes, are difficult for us. We like to talk, play, and think fast. Experts say we can't focus for more than about three minutes, which is too short for most classical pieces but perfect for a pop song. Pop music is simple and easy to listen to, while classical music needs time and focus. Pop songs also talk about things that interest teenagers more than long classical pieces without lyrics. The way we listen to music has changed too. In the past, families played music together at home, and playing an instrument was important. The only other way to hear music was at a concert. Now, you can find any music online, but we rarely listen to classical music. When was the last time you heard classical music in a shop? One of my teachers says more people are going to classical concerts now, but I doubt many of them are teenagers. In my orchestra, we play classical music in many places, but I mostly see older people in the audience. I don't know why people like classical concerts more as they get older, but I do know that if your parents love something, you might avoid it. Some people blame schools for teenagers not liking classical music, but many kids are excited to play in their school orchestra. They come early to practice and stay late to rehearse. They enjoy classical music when they play it, but it's not their first choice when they relax. For relaxing, it's always pop music.

Bonnie Wyndham got out of her mother’s car and looked at Almonside School. "I’ll make you sorry I’ve come here," she said to the school, smiling. Her mother was getting out of the car too, but she didn’t hear Bonnie. Bonnie didn’t mind if her mother heard because she already knew how Bonnie felt. Mrs. Wyndham looked around. Almonside was a strange school, with buildings hidden among the trees on a hillside. It was confusing at first. Then she saw signs on a post: Science block, gymnasium, riding centre… "Riding centre," Bonnie said, suddenly interested. "Headmaster’s study," her mother said. "This way." Bonnie followed her mother along a wide path between the trees. "I wish you’d walk beside me instead of following me like a dog," said Mrs. Wyndham tiredly, but she didn’t expect Bonnie to change. A few minutes later, her mother was talking to Bonnie’s new headmaster in his office, while Bonnie waited outside. Suddenly, Bonnie stood up. "Why should I just sit here?" she thought. "I’ll be kicked out soon anyway," she thought to herself, "so why not start now?" She left the building and went to the riding centre, following the sign. There was an old building for the horses and a large indoor riding area. Bonnie looked around, but no one was there. She approached the horses with respect. Bonnie always treated horses well. The horses were well cared for, she could see that right away. Almost every stall had a horse, and she walked along, looking at each one carefully. "I know what they’re doing here," she told a small pony as she touched its nose. The next horse surprised her. "Aren’t you the best one here!" she said. He was brown with a bit of white. He looked lively, but Bonnie liked that. "I feel like we’ve met before," Bonnie said, stroking his neck. "In my dreams, I was riding you to win a big competition…" His name was Maverick. Suddenly, she wanted to ride him. "I wonder where I can find a bridle and a saddle for you. They must be nearby." The room with all the riding equipment was unlocked, which made Bonnie happy. She was so focused on putting a saddle on Maverick that she forgot about her mother and the headmaster. When she sat on the big horse outside, she felt like a queen. Her nickname at her old school was Queen Bee, and she laughed as she remembered it. "You’re the best horse I’ve ever ridden, Maverick," she said, "and I mean it because I know about horses, even if I don’t know much else." She made him walk, then trot. "If I stay here, I think we could be great friends," she said. She rode around the paddock. The movement was exciting, and the breeze made her cheeks glow. She could tell Maverick trusted her, and she was sure he would jump well.

I’ve met Cody Simpson before and have always been impressed by how quietly confident he is. Cody is a 15-year-old from Australia who has already released many successful songs. So how did a relaxed surfer end up performing on stage for thousands of fans? Cody explains, "I first picked up a guitar when I was six and started writing songs at seven." He remembers how it all started. "But I was also swimming every day and surfing. Those were more important to me back then. I had my life planned out and was busy. I was 13, going to high school, and then I posted a few videos online." These videos changed everything. He started by posting a video of him and a friend singing at a school concert. Fans commented online, asking for more videos on their social media. So Cody, who had recorded more videos at home, was happy to share them. The responses were amazing. Cody was also a very talented swimmer. He trained hard with top coaches and focused on improving his sport. But then record labels contacted him, and he had a tough choice: stay in Australia and keep swimming, or take a big risk by signing a deal and moving with his family to the US. Cody decided to take the risk. "It was very hard for me, especially at such a young age, to choose a career. Can you imagine, at 12 or 13, trying to decide what you want to do for the rest of your life?" He had to tell his swimming coach and friends that he was moving to the US. "It was a big surprise to most people. I’m kind of the quiet kid," he says, remembering their shocked faces. "I’m very modest, and I think it’s important to be that way in this crazy world." So Cody packed his bags and moved with his family halfway around the world, giving up one dream to try to make another come true. Although his family stays out of the spotlight and isn’t directly involved in his career, they support him from the background. Cody says it’s important to have a close group of great people around you to keep you grounded. Of course, we all have days of doubt. "Sometimes when I’m alone, I think, ‘How did my decision affect my little brother and sister?’ My little brother is eight years old, and he’s traveling the world, doing school on the road; he doesn’t have a regular life," Cody admits. "I worry about how that affects him sometimes, but my family always reassures me that they’re here to support and encourage me in everything I do." Success, in any career, comes from being willing to say "yes" to your big opportunity, even when it’s a bit scary. "It all happened so fast and unexpectedly," Cody says. "Now, to be visiting countries I never thought I’d see and playing in front of hundreds of thousands of fans – it’s like something many people dream of and try to achieve. But I know it won’t last forever."

I jumped out of bed, pulled back the bedroom curtain, and looked at the river. A new crack in the ice shone in the morning sun. I shaded my eyes and looked upstream at the sandbags, which were there to stop the buildings from flooding when the ice melted. My back still hurt from lifting those sandbags. Last week, I worked with most of the town's adults for long hours to show I could do it. But my grandfather didn't seem to notice. With one hand on the curtain, I looked at the half-mile stretch of dark water created by the factory's release pipe in Milltown. There was thin ice on both sides, and the dark water was followed by solid ice downstream. As I took off my pajamas and reached for my kayaking wetsuit, I saw a boy on the other side of the river. I didn't know him. I frowned. He was trying to balance on an ice shelf near the warm water from the factory. I zipped up my wetsuit and grabbed my kayaking jacket. I checked the pocket for the lucky silver chain my famous grandfather brought back from South America. It's better than having a famous grandfather because only he, my mom, and I know about it. Plus, I have his diary from that trip. I keep it under my pillow and read it before I sleep. I touched the chain again and went to the kitchen. ‘Morning, Rex,’ Mom said with a smile as I took a banana from the counter. ‘You’re up early for a Saturday. I’ll make brunch after your training. Be careful.’ ‘Thanks, Mom.’ I walked down the hallway and almost bumped into Grandpa as he came out of his room. ‘Watch where you’re going!’ he shouted. ‘Where are you going?’ ‘Sorry, Grandpa. I’m going kayaking.’ My wetsuit should have made that clear. He sees me in my kayak every morning. Grandpa is Grandpa, and I try to ignore it when he gets angry, but it's getting harder. ‘Why train? You didn’t win the competition,’ he said. His words hurt, but I took a deep breath and counted to three. He went into the bathroom and slammed the door. Mom gave me a sympathetic smile. ‘Don’t mind him. He’s…’ ‘…not himself right now,’ I finished for her. I didn’t say he’s always been like that. But, like Mom, I try to be patient with him. When I was a child, he was my hero. He showed me photos of himself in National Geographic. Those old photos still hang on his bedroom wall, above his dusty medals and trophies. But I don’t go into his room anymore. I have my own growing collection of trophies to look at and, maybe soon, my own face in National Geographic. Still, a part of me wants to stay loyal to him, this grumpy old man. Mom smiled. ‘At least he’s coming out of his room more. Have a good session, Rex. I admire your determination, even on cold days!’ I smiled back as I peeled my banana. ‘It’ll be warmer in South America,’ I said. ‘If I find sponsors for my expedition.’ She laughed and went back to the kitchen. I ate my banana and went downstairs. I hurried to the boathouse in the backyard.

Mum grabbed Jess by the arm. "Come with me," she said. Jess followed her to the study. On the table, leaning against the wall, was an unframed painting. It was clearly one of Grandpa's, but it looked different from his other works and wasn't finished. "Do you know anything about this?" Mum asked. Jess shook her head. "I've never seen it before. I didn't know he was working on anything." Jess looked at the picture. It showed a river that took up most of the scene. It wasn't a river she knew and maybe not even a real one, just an imaginary river. The picture was strange and shapeless, but beautiful in a mysterious way. The riverbank was barely noticeable, just a hint of green, and the eye was drawn to the pale waters leading to a hidden sea. There were no animals, birds, or people, and it felt right that way. It seemed like there was no place for living things in this distant vision. Yet, for some reason, she was fascinated, thinking of autumn coming after a long, rich summer. Mum spoke again. "It has a name." There was something in her voice—too casual, too detached—that showed her excitement. Jess knew why. Grandpa never named his pictures. He just painted them and let others figure them out if they could. Mum turned the picture over and pointed to the words Grandpa had written. Jess read them aloud. "River Boy." The words seemed important to her, but she didn't know why. There was another mystery. She looked at Mum. "There is no boy." "Exactly. Strange, isn't it—for him to be so specific. Maybe he's going to add the boy later. I made the mistake of asking him about it." "Mum! You should have known better." "I know, but I couldn't help it. It's such an unusual picture, especially with a name. I guess you can imagine his response." Jess didn't need to guess. She knew what Grandpa would have said. "He told you it's not up to the artist to explain a painting because each picture has its own life and language, like a poem, and we either understand it or we don't. And he said painting is hard enough without having to explain it to everyone..." "Ignoramus, he said." "... every ignoramus what it means. And if artists had to explain their pictures to everyone, they'd never get any work done. And he said..." Mum interrupted her, laughing. "Something like that. Anyway, I was hoping you might know something about this painting since you seem to be a sort of muse for him." "Muse?" "Someone who inspires an artist." She knew what the word meant. Grandpa often used it when she watched him paint, but usually, he said the muse wasn't being kind to him today, or he had to be nice to the muse because he had a difficult part to work on. He never suggested the muse had anything to do with her. She always thought he meant some kind of goddess, not a human. And it was hard to imagine anyone, even a goddess, having any influence over someone as stubborn as Grandpa. "He doesn't need me to inspire him," she said. "He's been painting all his life."

When I woke up this morning, I didn't plan to cut a hole in my bedroom carpet. I'm not saying it was an accident, but it could have been. For example, if I had tripped over the bed with Dad's Stanley knife in my hand, the blade might have accidentally cut the carpet. I'm not saying that happened, just that it could have. I didn't wake up thinking, "Today I will cut a hole in my carpet." It just seemed like a good idea at the time, as things often do. Later, you wonder why you thought that, but by then it's too late. This happens to me a lot. I'm unlucky that way.

What I was really trying to do was find a way to fit my corner cabinet into a corner. Gran gave me the cabinet when she moved to a flat. It's really cute! It's small, painted white, with pink and blue flowers around the edge, and has tiny glass doors. Gran used to keep china ornaments in it, like shepherdesses and milkmaids. I keep my collection of shells, fossils, and interesting stones there. Gran knew I always loved her corner cabinet, so I was excited when she gave it to me! But it's a corner cabinet, shaped like a triangle, so it has to stand in a corner.

I only have two corners in my bedroom because it's the smallest room in the house, shaped like a wedge of cheese. The big front bedroom is Mum and Dad's; the one at the back is my sister Angela's; the little one over the garage is my brother Tom's; and the tiny one, like a broom cupboard, is mine. Mum says when Angela goes to University, Tom can have her room, and I can have his. But since Angela is only fifteen, I'll be in my small room for years. I don't mind; I like my little bedroom. It's cosy, like a nest. I love the sloping roof and the window at floor level. The only problem is the lack of corners! My bed is in one corner, and my wardrobe in the other. I tried fitting Gran's cabinet between the roof and the floor, but it was just a bit too tall. If I could only take a couple of centimetres off the bottom of it...

Then I had an idea. If I couldn't cut the cabinet, how about cutting a hole in the carpet? It seemed like the obvious solution. Dad calls this lateral thinking. I thought he would be pleased with me because he always tells us to "think outside the box." And that's exactly what I was doing!

The novel 'The Borrowers' is about a family of tiny people who live hidden in a house. They secretly take things from the normal-sized people to survive. When I was asked to direct a TV version of the novel, I knew it would be hard to meet people's expectations. Fans of the book have strong ideas about how everything should look. I used the original drawings from the book a lot because I didn't want people to say I got it wrong. The author wanted the series to show the Borrowers' point of view, not the humans', which made filming more complicated. The most important thing was getting the size right. The Borrowers are ten times smaller than humans, so when we filmed them walking across a room or going on a mission, we had to be 10 times further away than usual. When filming the human surroundings, the crew had to crawl on the ground and film from no higher than 15 centimeters to get the Borrowers' perspective. They wore out many pairs of jeans doing this! We never raised the cameras above their height except for aerial shots. One big challenge was getting the shadows right when combining images of the tiny Borrowers with normal-sized backgrounds. We created a special technique for this. After the series aired, the famous US film director George Lucas called to ask how I did it. The only permanent set we built was the Borrowers' home under the floorboards, filled with giant objects to make the actors look small. It was wonderfully surreal. When I asked them to carry things like a giant pair of scissors, they really got into it. I especially remember the coins - they were bigger than dinner plates and hard to lift. We often had to stop filming because they made the crew laugh so much. In the story, there’s a scene where the Borrowers are swept down a drain. To film this, actors had to be swept down a tunnel with hoses, and they said it was so scary they didn’t have to act. One important thing for me was getting the costumes right, which other directors struggled with. I had them made from heavy canvas so they stuck out like dolls’ clothes. This made it hard for the lead actress to bend in her costume. She couldn’t sit during breaks and had to be sewn into the dress every morning. The lead actor's trousers were made from a rug because normal material would look too smooth. Unfortunately, the weather was really hot during filming. I don’t think they thanked me for my attention to detail with those costumes! Most of the action away from the Borrowers’ home was filmed with the actors separated from their surroundings. We filmed them in front of a blue screen on an empty set. It was hard for them to react to things that weren't there. I had to draw pictures of every scene to show how each one should look – I did 2,000 of them by the end. They weren’t very accurate, but they worked well enough. The budget didn’t allow for time in special effects studios during the day, so I worked nights for three months. We had to work quickly – I once shot a whole scene before realizing there was no film in the camera. But it all came together in the end, and I think the series successfully captured the magic of the books.

Mom stops the car at the corner of my new school, Palm Grove High School. She looks around nervously, checking for journalists who aren't there. I wonder how long it will take before the chaos starts. It always does. The fake smiles, people pretending to be friends, and the "can you get me free tickets to your dad's concerts?" questions. "Everything's going to be fine," I tell her. She kisses her fingertip and touches my cheek before I get out of the car. Then she drives away, leaving me to face this new school and new situation. But this is what I wanted. I wanted to leave my old life of traveling and tutors. So while the rest of the band is staying here to record, we're staying for good. I chose this school because I want to meet real kids. Maybe a kid with a mom who works in an office or a dad who mows lawns. That would be so cool. So normal. 

I walk into the school's main office. "Hi, I need my schedule, please," I tell the school secretary. "Name?" She looks as friendly as an ice bucket. "Desert McGraw." "Desirée?" she asks, leaning closer. "Desert," I repeat. The secretary seems confused. "Oh," she says and types "McGraw" on her keyboard. That's one good thing. Few people recognize my last name because my dad uses a stage name. "What grade?" "Eleventh." "One second, it's printing," the secretary says. She hands me the schedule. English Literature, first period. Cool, I can handle that. English has always been my favorite subject. I'll be late, though. English is in Room 214, second floor. I studied the map last night so I wouldn't look lost. When I reach the door, I hear the teacher taking attendance. "Aurelio Gonzalez." "Here." I slip in quietly and sit at the last desk in the second row. The girl next to me smiles. Her eyes look over my normal outfit – jeans and a T-shirt. Ha! No one will suspect me now! "Nice shoes," she whispers. I look down at my expensive shoes with embroidered flowers. Oh no, I knew I shouldn't have worn these. They give me away. "Thanks," I say. The teacher pauses. "Desert... McGraw?" she says. "Here." The teacher smiles and introduces herself as Ms. Smigla. She talks a lot and gives us our course outlines. After we review them and she tells us about the books we need to read this year, she actually gives us time to talk! All teachers should do this. "So why'd you move here?" my new friend asks. I have many choices here. Do I say it's because I wanted a normal life away from cameras and reporters? Or the real reason, according to Dad? "We need a change, Desert," he said, "and this is the perfect place to record the new album. Energy, color, culture... just what our last album needed." Personally, I think he just wants to relax on the beach. Why else would they choose South Beach Sounds, a studio near the sand? "My dad had to relocate," I tell her. Yes, lies work better. "What does he do?" she asks. Oh well, everyone will find out eventually. But at least I can pretend to be normal for a while. "He's an artist," I say, playing with my backpack zipper. "Cool. I'm Becca, by the way." And she doesn't seem to care. Excellent.

The average American teenage girl today is expected to do many things. She should be the Student Council president, have a part-time job, volunteer, and do well in all these areas. This is what it means to be a teenager in America now. Teenage boys and girls can't just go to school and be average anymore. Being average is not enough, and not having big goals is seen as being lazy. 

Teenager Kristen Loose explains that people, especially adults, often forget how much pressure teenagers face today. They have lots of homework, tests, extra activities, jobs, chores, and responsibilities at home, all while trying to have a social life. Even though these pressures are normal for teenagers now, negative stereotypes about them still exist. People in the media often describe teenagers as lazy, disrespectful, rebellious, loud, reckless, and self-centered. While some teenagers might fit these descriptions, it is not fair to say all teenagers are like this.

Kristen Loose says that many people think teenagers spend most of their time watching TV or using their phones. She believes this is mostly wrong. She admits she keeps her phone close most of the day, but not just for fun. It is a tool that helps teenagers manage their lives better. Today, students are expected to have quick access to information and be reachable all the time, which can look like a phone addiction. With smartphones, tablets, and social media, students can do their work anywhere. Instead of listening to music on the way to school, they might listen to language lessons. Schoolwork and activities now need attention all day, adding to the stress of busy teenagers.

Many teenagers start their day at 6 or 7 a.m. and finish after midnight. Their day is full of school, activities, family duties, and homework. They often get less than the recommended nine hours of sleep each night. The US National Sleep Foundation found that only about 20% of teenagers get enough sleep. Also, 28% of teenagers said they fall asleep in school at least once a week because they are so tired.

Teenager Lindamarie Olsen says she has about 18 hours of free time each week after all her activities. With 168 hours in a week, 18 hours is not much. Olsen does not spend much of this time on social media or TV. Instead, she uses her energy to volunteer. She says that people think teenagers only care about themselves and their own interests. But Olsen's favorite part of the week is volunteering. She enjoys helping others and wants to make a positive impact in her school and community.

In 20 years, the stereotype of teenagers might change, but they will still be proving it wrong and pushing the world forward. There will be a new generation of students making a big impact, even before they finish school.

The teenage members of the Earth to Sky Calculus Club live near Bishop, a small town in the US surrounded by nature, east of the Sierra Nevada mountains. In recent years, this group has sent over fifty balloons to the edge of space, about 35 km above the Earth. This is a long-term science project with a twist: it's part astronomy experiment, part outdoor adventure, which attracts teenagers. I joined them one weekend in late spring. They were about to launch a high-altitude balloon to try to record shooting stars. Shooting stars happen when a rock or metal piece from space enters the Earth's atmosphere, creating a light trail. As it got dark, the teenagers attached a soft insulated $5 lunch box to the balloon. Inside, there was a camera, an instrument to measure altitude, and a thermometer to check temperature changes during the ascent. Two GPS trackers were placed outside the lunch box to help find it later. A gas tank, donated by someone from a nearby state, was used to fill the balloon, which grew to the size of a small car. An older boy had driven seven hours to get the gas tank. ‘I didn’t really mind,’ he said. For kids in this club, that's normal. Finally, it was time to launch. ‘Five, four, three, two, one,’ they counted, and the balloon started to rise. Some of them ran and followed its path with strong flashlights, lighting up the balloon in the dark sky. There was silence and a shared feeling of wonder. Then the balloon disappeared into the night. After the launch, most students went home, but a few stayed to watch the shooting stars. They lay on blankets on the mountainside and looked at the clear sky, hard to believe it was just four hours from Los Angeles, a busy city with about 4 million people. I saw a boy get into a sleeping bag and quickly fall asleep. ‘We're the only ones talking,’ said one girl quietly. ‘I know,’ whispered another. A meteor shot across the sky. As the balloon rises, the air pressure decreases, and the balloon expands until it's almost the size of a house. Then it bursts in a dramatic explosion. A parachute helps the equipment inside the lunch box land safely back on Earth. The students will find it the next day, using the GPS trackers. Getting it back isn’t easy, but that’s part of the fun. There is little inhabited land around Bishop, so the lunch box usually lands in remote areas. ‘To me, recoveries are a big part of the program,’ said the group’s leader, who noted they've lost only two lunch boxes in 53 launches. ‘Part of the journey is getting to know this landscape in a way you normally wouldn’t.’ This time, the lunch box landed 84 km west of Bishop, but to reach it, the recovery team had to drive south of the Sierra and then back up the western side of the mountains. Then they had to decide whether to drive or walk – it could be dangerous if the lunch box was on a high peak or, even worse, up a very tall tree. ‘It's important to remember that these students are from the Eastern Sierra,’ their leader says. ‘What may seem wild and dangerous to some is just a way of life to others.’ In the end, it took them 11 hours to find the lunch box. It was in a canyon, high on a flat rock, in the middle of a waterfall. The camera hadn't recorded any shooting stars. Sure, it's a bit disappointing, but it's also a chance to discuss the effects of atmospheric waves and how they might work above mountain ridges. And it's also another adventure story to share with anyone who asks.

Chloe Morgan admits that she wasn't very interested in science, especially Palaeontology, until she was fifteen. Her interest started by accident. Her younger brother was really into dinosaurs, a common interest for kids, but Chloe wasn't. She helped him with a science project and found an article about new discoveries in Palaeontology. It amazed her, and she realized she wanted to pursue it.

I asked Chloe about the support she received because Palaeontology wasn't a typical career choice for young people then. She remembers meeting her first professional palaeontologist, Matt Cornelius, who was already famous despite being young. Chloe was nervous at first, worried he might find her annoying with her questions. But he was patient and willing to listen, which made her feel more comfortable.

I mentioned how palaeontologists are shown in movies and TV shows. Chloe thinks films like Jurassic Park have increased interest in dinosaurs but not necessarily in Palaeontology. She feels movies often show palaeontologists as either eccentric geniuses or awkward geeks, which isn't accurate. Her job is varied; she digs up dinosaur bones, works in labs analyzing fossils, and writes for scientific publications. She also believes in explaining science to the public, especially young people, to clear up misunderstandings and get them interested in science.

Chloe was involved in the TV documentary Walking with Dinosaurs. She says the program makers knew what they were doing, and she was there to advise if needed. She mostly checked that the dinosaurs shown lived in the same time period. The program attracted audiences of all ages because it showed dinosaurs in a new, more realistic way compared to movies like Jurassic Park.

I asked Chloe why dinosaurs continue to fascinate us. She thinks they appeal to our sense of exploration and discovery. Even though our world feels smaller, prehistoric creatures remind us there's still more to discover. Palaeontology, she says, is like a form of time travel.

I'm going to say this once: when you're traveling by car with your family, even if you're six years old, you probably know you're not "there yet," even if you keep asking, "Are we there yet?" And really, once you get there, it's not "there" anymore; it's "here." So if you think you might be "there," you should ask, "Are we here yet?" I'm sure no one wants to be "there" more than the parents who hear that question over and over during long car trips. Seriously, what are we kids complaining about? Think about it. Wouldn't you rather relax in the back seat, with nothing to do? You can watch DVDs, listen to music, or do puzzles while the scenery goes by outside the window. In the front seat, there's mom or dad, who gives out juice boxes and cookies, changes the radio station, and keeps everything running smoothly. Are we there yet? I hope not. That is, until someone in the car does something annoying—like my younger brother, Tim, putting his foot on my side of the seat. He can't do that! So I put my foot on his side. Then he puts his other foot, then a hand, and soon he's in my space, and we're fighting. The driver and co-pilot separate us while the car swerves. They tell the younger sibling to stay in his seat and keep his hands to himself. This calms things down for a while. The beautiful scenery continues to pass by. Soon after, I'm trying to read, and I feel a breeze on my arm. But the car isn't going fast, and the window isn't open. Where's it coming from? My brother is next to me, quietly blowing air on me. He's on his side, not touching me, so he's technically not doing anything wrong. Just breathing? What's the problem with that? I get angry. Tim gets yelled at, and there's more swerving. Then things calm down again—for now. Over the years, Dad has come up with ways to deal with us in the back seat. For example, when we ask, "Are we there yet?" he often says, "Yes. We're here. Get out of the car." "But Dad, we're still on the highway, going 70 miles an hour." "Oh, well, then maybe we're not there yet." That keeps us quiet for a while. You know you're finally "there" when the adults get out of the car and move far away from the kids who have bothered them for hours. So remember: if mom and dad are still close enough to answer your question, then the answer is no. You're not there yet.

John and Zuzi Morgan have opened a café in Oxford, UK, where people can enjoy coffee, cake, and play board games. They hope people will love the experience and come back. Zuzi explains that they wanted to create a place where people can connect without using technology. She says, "Everyone is busy with their phones and gadgets. We wanted to bring people together to communicate face-to-face."

The games played in their café are called 'Eurogames'. These games have gentle themes like farming and building landscapes. The first Eurogame was The Settlers of Catan, now known as Catan, created by Klaus Teuber from Germany. In this game, players build settlements on an island and trade resources, keeping everyone involved until the end. This idea was improved in 'co-operative' games, where players work as a team to win or lose together, encouraging more social interaction. 

One popular co-operative Eurogame is Pandemic, created by Matt Leacock from North America. In Pandemic, players work together to solve global problems. Leacock was inspired by a Eurogame called Lord of the Rings. He remembers playing it with friends and feeling scared but excited, and everyone felt good whether they won or lost. This inspired him to create games that bring similar feelings.

Leacock loved board games since he was a child, even though he often felt disappointed by them. With help from his uncle, he started designing better games. Pandemic became very successful, and its sequel included more storytelling, similar to video games where characters develop and the world changes.

Interestingly, the growth of video games has helped the success of modern board games. Video games have made playing games more normal. Ben Hogg, from a leading games company, says, "Everyone with a smartphone has at least one game they like to play." 

Video games used to offer social interaction in arcades or with friends at home. But as games moved online, players became more distant from each other. Some people who enjoyed video games started looking for ways to play games with others in person again.

John and Zuzi's café shows that tabletop gaming is more than just fun. In our online world, these games offer a way to connect with others in real life, and this trend is likely to continue.

Jamie Scott has written and produced some of the biggest UK hits in recent years. His story shows why endurance and persistence are important in the music business, even if your career starts with many challenges. Jamie says his mother was a great singer and she taught him to play the guitar. The only radio station he listened to at home was for middle-aged people, which influenced him as he grew up. He was 12 when he first heard a modern song. Around that time, he had to choose between tennis, which he played at a national level, and music. He spent his lunchtimes in the school music room playing the piano. He says, ‘I was good at tennis, but I didn’t want to do it for the rest of my life. It was too much hard work.’ At 17, he left school to become a performer. He was in a duo with a friend who was a good guitarist but not as interested in a music career. Jamie told his parents he wanted to pursue music, saying he wrote lyrics during economics lessons and played the piano every day. His dad gave him 18 months to succeed, or he would have to find a job. After some close calls with record labels, he was signed to a music publisher at 19 because of one song. However, record labels only wanted him as a solo artist, so he had to leave his friend. Eventually, he found success behind the scenes rather than on stage. After a tough time with a UK record label, he switched to another label to release a new album, but fame and fortune did not come. Jamie says, ‘In my artist career, I was often in the wrong place at the wrong time, but as a writer, I was in the right place at the right time.’ Writing for others is where he truly succeeded. He believes he is one of the main writers in the UK that labels send new artists to. This helps start their careers. Sometimes he explains to artists that writing with the charts in mind is okay. He asks, ‘Don’t you want 10 million people streaming your music next month?’ He believes they should write songs that are amazing and likely to sell well. It is refreshing to hear someone speak honestly about wanting to write number-one hits. Jamie is not arrogant; he just knows he wants to write hits and has the talent to do it. Instead of worrying about what others think, he focuses on his goal. ‘When I go into the studio, we aim to write the best music of next year. It’s not just about being cool. We want to write classic modern pop songs,’ he says.

Tony Connor is a new kind of celebrity. He is very famous online but might be unknown to people who don't watch videos of bike stunts. He is a 'street trials cyclist,' which means he jumps from places like roofs or walls to other unusual spots. These stunts are filmed and shared online.

When I met him at a BMX park on a Saturday morning, many local boys and older people recognized him and called him a 'legend.' After seeing his skills, I agreed. Even though I was doubtful at first, I was impressed by his bravery and creativity. Before each stunt, he explained what he planned to do, and I often doubted he could do it. But he always succeeded. When I praised him, he seemed not very interested. Despite his online fame, Tony says he doesn't like being a celebrity. He finds it hard to interact with fans and prefers doing things rather than talking about them.

This is interesting because his fame comes from social media and camera technology. He admits that this technology helps him make a living. However, he sometimes feels uncomfortable with everyone always using cameras and screens. Still, he is not complaining because he earns well from what used to be just a hobby.

From my experience interviewing top athletes, I know that two things are important to become a top competitor: energy and the ability to handle disappointment. These are more important than talent and help someone keep going despite failures. In risky sports, mental strength is crucial. Even in the park, Tony fell a few times on easy obstacles but kept trying until he succeeded.

Not everyone sees Tony as a hero. Some think he takes unnecessary risks. Tony says these people don't understand the sport and don't know he gets expert advice to reduce risks. He is careful about the risks he takes. He believes it's important to be aware of dangers. Some people never feel scared, but Tony feels fear and finds a way to overcome it. He is not addicted to risk and spends a lot of time planning. Sometimes he rides around to get in the right mindset before a new stunt. He knows he must stay calm before jumping. If he fully commits, he is fine.

Television presenter Helen Skelton has done many dangerous challenges for charity. She has run a marathon in the desert and traveled down the Amazon River in a small boat. Her latest challenge was walking on a high wire, which is a long, thin piece of metal, 66 meters above the ground. She walked between two towers of an empty power station. There was no safety net, only a belt around her waist connected to another wire above. To help her balance and not fall, she carried a long stick that weighed eight kilograms. Helen learned from an expert high-wire walker. Even though she had some circus skills, she found high-wire walking very different. "The training was a shock," said Helen. "I didn’t know how strong I needed to be. Every day started at 8 am with a run up a steep hill, then an hour of exercises, and another hour after practicing on the wire. I also had to learn how to fall onto the wire so that if I slipped, I could continue. Every time I fell on the wire, it hurt a lot. But it was important to stay positive: if I was nervous and started shaking, the wire would shake too!" On the day of the challenge, it was windy, and Helen stayed calm by taking deep breaths as she moved step by step along the wire. The 150-meter walk took 15 minutes. "That was the scariest thing I’ve done," she said afterward. "I’m glad it’s over!" Despite this, Helen is already planning her next charity project: to reach the South Pole by skiing, using a kite, and biking.

In 2006, Jeff Somers started a journey around the world on a penny farthing, which is an old-style bicycle with one large wheel and one small wheel. Before this, he had written a book about his travels in Canada using a 50-year-old car. Jeff loved motor sports and worked on building racing car engines. To save money, he rode an old bicycle to work and even used it to go on holiday to Amsterdam. ‘That trip opened my eyes,’ he says. ‘I decided to see the world by bike.’ Jeff didn’t want a regular touring bike and wanted to build one himself. ‘The craziest bicycle I could think of was a penny farthing, so I went to the museum to see how they were made.’ After two failed attempts in 2001 and 2003 due to a knee injury, he finally started his journey in 2006. He traveled for three years, visiting 23 countries on four continents. The best part of his trip was reaching Tibet and seeing Mount Everest. ‘Although I met cyclists who could ride up mountains on their bikes, which I couldn’t do, I never regretted my penny farthing. The further away from home I got, the more amazed people seemed by it.’ His worst moment was when he had to drink dirty water from a stream. He got a serious fever and was stuck in a hostel bed without medicine for ten long days. He had no money for hospital bills or to get back home. Despite all this, Jeff now says, ‘if I could afford it, I would set off traveling again tomorrow on my penny farthing.’

I work at a university in the US, where my team and I are studying water birds, especially the American black duck. We have just started using an exciting tool called a 'night-vision scope'. This tool helps us see the ducks in the dark! We are concerned about black ducks because their numbers have dropped a lot, and we are not sure if there is enough food for them on the east coast. We know a lot about what they do during the day, but not at night, because we didn't have the right equipment before. This new scope will give us clear pictures, even on nights without moonlight, so we can learn more and make better decisions about how to protect their habitat based on what we find out. The work is very hard. There are four of us, and each of us works six hours a day. We have studied ducks in different places, and I have had to take a boat to some sites and write down notes on every duck I see. The weather has been difficult – some nights are mild, but more often it is wet. Also, it is so quiet that I need a lot of coffee to stay awake! We have only missed one day of work so far because the snow was too deep, even for our special snow vehicles. Still, I enjoy the challenge, especially compared to what summer will bring – hours in a laboratory, where we will look at our results together. It will be hard to be inside, but it is important to do this. And I wouldn't change it for anything!

When I tell people about my job, they can hardly believe it exists. But it's true! I spend my workdays eating chocolate. Tasting chocolate is very important to make sure customers get perfect, high-quality chocolate bars from the company I work for. Every week, I get small samples from our factory to check their taste, texture, and smell. I also taste the raw materials we use, like nuts and fruit, and spend time choosing the best ones for the chocolate. Next to my office, I have a kitchen where I can test and taste the products I make, and I keep my coworkers happy by giving them samples! My kitchen is full of machines and ingredients to experiment with. It's great to have a private space to go to during the day. No two days are the same in this job. Sometimes I'm at our food lab, and other times I'm traveling to buy raw materials. Since I have a young family, traveling can be hard. But I love the variety and lack of routine in this job, although I think the chocolate itself is the best part! People often ask if I get tired of chocolate. I've worked with it for a long time, and I've never felt like I didn't want to eat it. In fact, I often go home and eat more chocolate in the evening!

Have you ever thought about what it's like to perform in a circus? Sophia Grayson is from Circus Experience, a place where young people learn circus skills. She says her course is popular because it teaches many skills, like juggling, throwing and catching things like balls or even fire, and trapeze, which means flying through the air above an amazed audience. During the year-long course, students slowly take more risks in each class, and parents can come to some classes to see how they are doing. Sophia explains, “For a circus career, performers need to avoid doing the same thing all the time – it’s important to keep performances exciting and full of action. If you want to be successful in the circus, you must keep practising. Another great part is making friends with other performers and learning from them. Being fit is also very important - circus artists, like athletes, train every day to stay strong. Training is very important, but the best performers are those who want success, have imagination, and never stop improving their skills. People often think you might get injured or that you might only work for a short time each year. But, actually, the real issue is planning for the future because you can only travel with the circus while you’re young, and then you need to think about other options.” The course also teaches business planning. Many former students start businesses all over the world and are happy to share their experiences. Sophia warns, however, it’s not a job for making money! “The work usually means not having a regular salary. It’s also competitive - but great fun!”

You might not know her name or recognize her face, but you've probably heard her voice many times. Mariam Hobson is a professional backing singer. She supports the main singer by singing in the background. Some people think backing singers aren't good enough to be lead singers, but that's not true. They often need to be even better. People like Mariam are the real stars of the music industry! 

"What I love about my job is that when I go into the recording studio, I never know what I'll be asked to sing," she says. "It could be classical, jazz, hip-hop, or rock. Or it might be a funny little tune for a radio station or an advertisement. I'm often surprised by what producers ask for. Once, I was asked to sing like a fish underwater! But I never argue; I just do the job!"

"Excellent musical skills are essential for my work, plus the ability to learn quickly. There's often no written music to look at. I'll never forget my first time recording background music for a film. It was very complicated because there were eight of us, each singing a different tune, and an orchestra too. I was scared because if I made a mistake, we would have to record everything again, which nobody likes. Recording sessions are long enough already."

"One of my favorite jobs is recording for songwriters. Less experienced writers don't always know which musical range is best for the female voice. By listening to me sing their song, they can figure out how to improve it."

Julie Deane started her business with only basic knowledge of fashion. She created a successful company selling 'satchels,' which are traditional bags used by schoolchildren. These bags are now sold in famous shops and are popular with many celebrities. Before choosing to make satchels, Julie considered different business ideas, like cake decorating and party planning. She didn't just go with her first idea. When she decided on satchels, not everyone agreed with her choice. Julie says, "Many said there was no demand for them – but I was convinced." She worked with her family from the beginning, especially her mother, who had never had a career but had a natural talent for business. The design of the satchels was inspired by children's storybooks. 

Even though Julie didn't know much about fashion blogs, they played a big role in her success. At first, she sold about one satchel a week. To get more attention, Julie sent satchels to fashion writers, hoping they would write about them in their blogs. They did, and interest in her satchels grew. Her company now makes satchels faster than before. Julie enjoys seeing which celebrity is pictured with a satchel. Instead of spending money on online ads, she uses the internet community to get ideas for new styles, keeping her products fresh and exciting.

There was a difficult time when another company copied Julie's satchel design to sell similar products. Because of this, she now makes sure she trusts her production team as much as her own staff. Visitors to her office often comment on the positive atmosphere – people enjoy working there. There is now a new factory, and while the building is important, it's the team that makes it a special place.

When Vicky Harmiston was a child, her parents let her and her brother Jamie choose what to do in their free time. Vicky decided to try many different sports. She was a good swimmer, and her coach thought she could become a champion. However, the swimming club was far from her home, making it hard to balance training with her schoolwork. 

When they were teenagers, Jamie, who loved cycling, bought a special racing bike and started competing. Vicky thought it looked exciting and decided to try cycling too. She says it was the best decision she ever made. Soon, she was cycling every day and doing very well. The track was close to her school, so she could easily attend training sessions after school.
