In a relaxed and welcoming environment, she let them try on as many hats as they needed to find the right one. With changing rooms available, she encouraged customers to bring their outfits so nothing was left to chance. She recently expanded her business to sell handbags and costume jewelry as well.

It's a long journey from London to Atlanta, and Lawrence Okoye is thinking about his amazing sports career at his new home in America. He is confident, but even he is surprised by how far he has come—from competing in the Olympic discus final to possibly joining a major American football team. Lawrence has never played American football before, but he might be chosen for one of the top teams in the USA. In Atlanta, he is still learning about his new position in the sport. The idea that a 21-year-old from London could be picked for a big American sports team is surprising. But Lawrence is used to proving people wrong. He was offered a place at Oxford University to study law but decided to focus on discus instead, after playing rugby. In just 20 months, he became the fourth-best discus thrower in the world. Lawrence originally went to Atlanta for warm-weather discus training to prepare for the world championships. When asked about his sudden interest in a big NFL contract, Lawrence says, "American football was in the back of my mind, but I decided to try it when I got to the USA. I thought about it in school, but it seemed crazy then." Soon after arriving in America, he learned about NFL trials in Atlanta. Even though he had never played, he thought he might be good enough to try out. "Pretty much," he says. "I went online and applied." Was he nervous about competing with experienced American football players? "No," he says. "I don't get nervous about many things." Lawrence is not very talkative, but he believes in his abilities. His performance in tests and drills made him stand out as the most impressive player. "I was very pleased to hear that," he says, showing a rare sign of pride. However, he is also cautious. Lawrence has no experience in American football. How can he make it into an NFL team? "Coaches say I have all the qualities needed. It's just about how hard I work," he replies. Is he relaxed while waiting to hear if he has been selected? "I am. There's no pressure on me. Many people say I'll be selected, but I'm not too worried." This calm attitude might come from his disappointing Olympic discus final, where he finished last. He seems to have moved on from that experience and is happy he made it to the final with an impressive last throw. "That was an amazing day," he says. "The final didn't go as I wanted, but that's part of sport. I can always go back to it." After his Olympic disappointment, some thought the event had affected him. Lawrence doesn't comment on this. The minimum salary for an NFL player is over $400,000 a year, so the financial benefits are clear. Lawrence has switched from rugby to athletics and now to American football. With his great physical abilities, wouldn't it be better to focus on one sport? "I understand why someone would say that," he responds. "I'm trying to achieve something I've dreamed about since I was a schoolkid. If it doesn't work out, I can return to discus, the sport I love. Every decision I've made has been thought through."

We had been flying east all night, and I woke up to see it was already daylight. Looking out the window, I saw the empty landscape below. The dark shades of brown and green reassured me that, even though it was mid-September, it hadn't started snowing in Siberia yet. I couldn't see any signs of human life. The view was a mix of mountains, streams, and forests stretching to an endless horizon. I shook my head. My neighbor woke up and smiled at me sleepily. "Good morning, Robert," he said with a slow, Russian accent. Sergei was a salesman from Moscow. He was flying to a remote area to sell safety clothing to local mining industries. His English was almost as poor as my Russian, but with a dictionary, I explained that I was flying to the far-eastern Siberian city of Magadan with only a one-way ticket because I planned to return to England by bicycle. "But, Robert," he said, "there is no road from Magadan; you cannot ride a bicycle." I explained that I believed there was a road, though not many people used it these days. "Alone?" he asked, pointing at me. "No, I will be riding with a friend called Al." "Just one friend?" "Yes, just one," I nodded. Sergei still looked doubtful and said one word, "Holodna" (cold), pointing outside. I tried to reassure him with hand gestures that I had a lot of warm clothes, though I didn't mention that I was on a tight budget because my trip was self-funded. Most of my clothes and equipment were bought at low prices. I wasn't sure they would be good enough, especially my large postman's over-trousers, which I bought for £10. It all started in a lecture hall in Scotland. The hall was full of students slumped in their seats. Some were taking notes without energy. The lecturer droned on. I was thinking hard about a particular dilemma. Should I ask him or not? "Well, why not?" I tore a fresh sheet from my pad and wrote, "Hi Al, Do you want to cycle across the Karakorum Highway between Pakistan and China this summer? Rob." In the row in front of me was Al, my old school friend. I tapped him on the shoulder and passed the note. He tried to read my messy writing, scratched his head, wrote something, and passed it back. I unfolded it and held my breath while I read. "OK," it said. Six years later, I was going to join Al in Siberia. I had been working as a geography teacher, and although I was still far from having full control of my classes, the job was good for me. It was often challenging, rarely boring, often fulfilling, and, of course, there were long holidays to chase adventures. Twice since I started teaching, I used these holidays to meet Al. He had caught the adventure bug in a big way after our bike ride through Pakistan and decided to do something more relaxing than teaching: to cycle around the world. Ever since that first ride we took together, Al had been setting himself greater and greater challenges. This round-the-world-by-bike trip was his greatest so far. At times, he thought the ride or the road would break him. Although it sounded tough, I envied him in many ways. He was having an extraordinary adventure, finding that he could handle each new challenge even if it seemed impossible. He was proving wrong the people who said he couldn't do it. He was doing something that scared him nearly every day, and it made him feel alive.

In the Red Bull Air Race, twelve pilots take turns racing through tall pylons, which are 15 to 25 meters high. They make sharp turns, barrel rolls, and loops at speeds up to 370 km per hour. I was invited to experience what it's like to be part of this race. An hour before the flight, I had to sign two forms. The first form confirmed I was healthy, and the second said I would empty my pockets because small objects can be dangerous during the flight. I also learned I needed to stay oriented. "The horizon is your best friend," they told me, and the pilot would explain where to look. I was also asked to promise to relax and enjoy the view when flying upside down. 

Half an hour before the flight, I had a safety briefing. They told me not to touch anything. As we moved down the runway, my legs were up, trying not to touch the important steering pedals, and my hands were away from the switches. I decided I would not relax and enjoy the flight, despite the instructions. This is the challenge of high-speed acrobatic flying. To avoid passing out, you must stay calm and focused. You need to tense up and relax at the right times. Panicking is not a good idea. This was not comforting as we started accelerating. Dario, the pilot, and I reached the end of the runway in the Zivko Edge 540, one of the fastest acrobatic planes. The plane took off, and two seconds later, we turned sharply to the right. It was a sudden move, and I felt the air leave my lungs. I looked at the horizon, tensed up, and took short breaths as I sank into the seat. For a moment, I felt 6.2 times my normal weight. Then we leveled out. We turned sharply left and dived, leaving my stomach high up and my lungs feeling squeezed. Seconds later, we were 10 meters off the ground, heading for a small space between two pylons. They passed at 400 km per hour, but my excitement was cut short by a sharp right turn. We hadn't even done any acrobatics yet. 

For two minutes, I was allowed to fly the plane. My hand shook so much that the plane shook too because it was very responsive. Then Dario said something, and I asked him to repeat it. Instead of replying, he did a barrel roll, a full 360-degree turn. "Are you okay?" he asked. "Yup," I replied. "Have you had enough?" "No," I lied. Then he did a loop, flying the plane in a full circle in the air. I know many people would find this exciting, like those who enjoy rollercoasters. However, I thought it was too much. At the top of the loop, while flying upside down, I heard a small voice saying, "Relax, relax, look up." I looked up and saw some fields. The flight lasted 10 minutes. It was "soft" compared to what the pilots experience during a race. To show this, Dario got out some sandwiches and started eating happily as soon as we landed. I didn't eat for hours, and that night, I dreamed of doing loops over and over again.

Doug Allan films wild animals in cold places. If you've ever seen amazing footage of polar bears in a nature documentary, it was probably filmed by him. He says his perfect temperature is -18C. Allan trained as a marine biologist and commercial diver. Diving was his first passion, where he learned how to survive in cold places. His big opportunity came when a TV crew came to Antarctica, where Allan was working, to film a wildlife documentary. 'I ended up taking the crew to different places, and after 48 hours I realized that being a wildlife cameraman was perfect for me: travel, adventure, underwater.' He is now a top cameraman and has worked on many major TV wildlife series. 'I started at a good time. When I began, hardly anyone had been to the Antarctic. You had people who specialized in coral, elephants, chimpanzees. I just became the cold man. It was like all these amazing scenes were just waiting to be filmed.' The camera and communications technology was very basic when he started 35 years ago. 'It is certainly easier to film today. If you filmed something then, you had to remember it. Today, with digital technology, you can film a lot and look at it immediately. You used to have to think about what shots you needed next, and what you had missed. You filmed less. Film was very expensive. Today you can have too much material.' 'My value is field experience in cold conditions. I have a feel for it. I have spent so much time on sea ice it now feels like crossing the street. I do get cold toes but the poles are healthy places. There are no leeches, no diseases or mosquitoes.' Wildlife filming, Allan says, is full of great successes, but also failures and embarrassments. Once, he was in the Orkneys to film kittiwakes. Unfortunately, he could not identify which birds they were. When Allan recently got permission to film sequences for a major TV series in Kong Karls Land, a group of islands in the Arctic Ocean, he did not expect an easy job. It is a world of polar bears and is strictly off limits to all but the most fearless or foolish. Usually -32C in April, the wind is strong and carrying cameras in the deep snow is very difficult. After walking five or more hours a day and watching polar bear dens in the snow slopes for 23 days, however, Allan had seen just one mother bear and her cub. By day 24, though, he says, he was living in bear world, at bear speed, with bear senses. 'We find a new hole and wait. We move around to stay warm. Five hours of watching and then with no warning at all I catch a glimpse so brief that I almost miss it. But the camera’s locked on the hole on full zoom and my eye’s very quickly on the viewfinder. Nothing for a couple of seconds and then an unmistakable black nose. Nose becomes muzzle, grows bigger to become full head and in less than a minute she has her front legs out and is resting on the snow in front of the hole. She’s looking at me but she’s not bothered. I’ve just pulled out of a close-up thinking this can’t get much better … when she sets off on a long slide down the slope. I’d swear it’s partly in sheer pleasure,’ he recounts, adding that two cubs then appeared at the den entrance. ‘Clearly it’s their first view of the world … It’s show time on the slopes and we have front-row seats.’ Now Allan would like to make his own film about climate change in the Arctic, talking to the people who live there and experience the impact of it first hand. He says he would be able to make an extraordinary documentary.

In 2004, Pen Hadow became the first person to walk to the North Pole alone without getting more supplies on the way. He had to swim in very cold water and deal with frostbite and polar bears. Just eight months later, he reached the South Pole too. Now, he is back in the Arctic, getting ready for an even bigger expedition. Explorers are confident and determined people, and they need to be. This time, there is more at risk. Pen and two colleagues will go on a three-month, 1,000-kilometre journey to the North Pole. They will take detailed measurements of the ice's thickness and density. No one has done this before, and the results will be very important for scientists. This will give the clearest picture yet of how global warming is affecting the polar ice. Pen was trained for this kind of work. As a child, he was looked after by a woman who had worked for the famous explorer Scott of the Antarctic. She was hired to make him tough by sending him out into the Scottish mountains during blizzards with very few clothes. His father also loved adventures in cold places, and Pen showed he had great physical endurance. Pen is married to Mary, who loves the outdoors too. She helps run his polar guide business and says she worries more about him when he is at home because he is often thinking about the Arctic. For fun, she once raced against him in a mountain event where riders on horses compete against runners. Mary and her horse finished an hour before Pen. Pen and Mary live in the countryside with their two children. ‘It’s much harder to be away from them this time,’ he says. ‘They were one and five when I last went, and I made a mistake in how I said goodbye. I told my son, “You’re the man of the house now, look after your mum and your sister.” He took it very seriously, but it was too much pressure for him. It was well-meaning but unfair.’ Because of this, Pen plans to have little contact with his family while in the Arctic. ‘If you call them, you remind them how far away you are.’ He is spending his last days before leaving getting his equipment ready. ‘On the ice, you can’t fix things easily,’ he says. Ann Daniels, a top polar explorer, and Martin Hartley, the expedition photographer, will join him. They will have a team of six flying in supplies. Being part of a team is more stressful for Pen, and he is also worried about his age. ‘I’m going to be 47 on Thursday. I haven’t trained as much as I’d like.’ Why? ‘Organizing things always seems more urgent. So I’m almost afraid of what I’m going to ask of myself.’ Pen believes his mission connects exploration with the search for knowledge, like in the past. ‘Reaching the North Pole was a personal goal,’ he admits, ‘and not very useful to others. This time, scientists will benefit from the data, and we’re trying to involve as many people as possible in what’s happening in the Arctic Ocean. This is important work, and only we can do it,’ he says. ‘Our skills, which seemed strange and not useful before, are now very important. Suddenly, we’re useful to society again.’

I took a year off and wondered what to do next. Being an Olympian is amazing, and I had opportunities to write, work on TV, and speak at schools and businesses. These activities were great, but I missed having a competitive goal. I wanted to stay fit in case I decided to try for the Olympics again, so I started running marathons and doing triathlons. Even with these activities, I kept thinking about TV presenter Ben Fogle's invitation: "Do you want to row across the Atlantic with me?" I love rowing and missed the feeling of the boat moving through the water, but I wasn't ready to train every day. Still, I wanted some kind of competition. I asked my rowing friends if they were interested in the race, but no one was excited. I knew if I joined the race, I would want to win. I wondered if rowing with Ben would give me the best chance to win. Probably not, but being an underdog with no pressure was interesting. I contacted Ben. He was already planning to do the race and had managed to gather the entry fee and deposit for a boat, making the race a real possibility. We talked about the costs; the boat and equipment alone would cost £70,000, which is a lot. We thought we had a good chance, but it would still be hard work to make it happen. Besides the race costs, I also had to consider losing income from being away. As a retired athlete, speaking at business events is a good way to earn money. It's nice that people are interested, but I find it hard to talk about past achievements without a new goal. Doing the race would mean I could talk about something current, like rowing across the Atlantic. Planning this adventure taught me to appreciate the easier life of a full-time athlete. Preparing for the Olympics was tough, but looking back, it was straightforward. I trained almost every day, but I had a set program and support from doctors and dieticians. I worried about what people would think of me racing with a TV presenter. I was concerned it might seem like I just wanted to be on TV, instead of choosing a better partner to win. But during our preparations, my worries faded. The Atlantic Rowing Race is more about mental strength than just rowing. Ben had done the tough Marathon des Sables, spent time at sea, and lived on a deserted island. However, he couldn't row well. I was surprised by his lack of skill, and he was surprised by my lack of patience. I could have been more patient, but I needed to be honest about the improvements he needed. I should have known his skill level when I agreed to race with him.

Just over a year ago, I left my job to work with huskies in the Arctic Circle, in the far north of Finland. At 26, I felt restless. I dreamed of Arctic landscapes, cold and empty spaces, maybe because of the noise and crowded life in London. I found a small company run by Anna McCormack and her husband, Pasi Ikonen, in Finnish Lapland. They agreed to hire me as a husky dog handler for a busy winter season. From December to February, they take tourists on sled rides pulled by huskies across the ice and snow, for trips lasting from an hour to five days. They started with six dogs, which quickly grew to more than 100. Recently, they took over a second place called the 'wilderness farm', which they said was a beautiful but simple place with unreliable electricity and no running water. They told me I could join the team for three months if I knew what I was getting into. 'The hours are long, the conditions tough, and the work very physical.’ I started packing right away.

November 6, London On my flight, I look at a page with more than 100 pictures of huskies. I am supposed to memorize their names before I arrive, but I feel distracted and nervous. I put the page down and look out of the window instead. People say that spring moves north at about 26 km per day, like a wave of flowers and leaves opening. But I think I am seeing the opposite, with winter moving south and the rivers freezing.

November 7, Helsinki and Hetta The bus going north is everything I hoped for. We drive through endless dark forests with thin conifers covered in snow, stopping sometimes to let reindeer move out of the way. I arrive at the farm after dark and am barely inside when I’m given a pair of boots and sent out into the cold. 'Do you want to be thrown in at the deep end?’ Anna asks. It’s a rhetorical question. I follow the sound of barking, which becomes very loud by the time I reach the dog sheds. Three people are running back and forth, pulling out huskies and harnessing them to sleds. The dogs are almost crazy with excitement, pulling hard on the ropes because they want to go. I can barely hear to introduce myself, but the others are too busy to talk much anyway. I stand on the side and rub the forehead of one of the quieter dogs. Someone gestures at me impatiently – 'Get in!’ – and I almost fall into the nearest sled. A command is given, and with a jerk, we are off into the dark, with only a head torch for light.

November 15, Hetta It doesn’t take long to become part of the husky guides, but not before a discouraging questioning about what I bring to the group. 'Are you useful?’ Anna asks. I’m unsure. I don’t know. Am I? More questions show that no, I am not: I have never driven a snowmobile, haven’t done woodwork since school, and have never chopped anything with an axe. 'You do have a driving licence?’ someone asks finally. I nod, relieved. The basics of dog-sledding can be learned quickly: lean into the corners, put both feet on the brake to stop, and, whatever happens, don’t let go of the handlebar. But everything else seems very complicated. Simple tasks like feeding and watering the dogs become very difficult in freezing conditions. A bowl of water will freeze solid while you watch, so we must make a 'soup’ of meat in hot water for the dogs. By the end of my first week, my head is spinning with instructions, and my muscles ache from dragging heavy sleds – and from being dragged around by overexcited huskies. But I feel triumphant. 'I can chop with an axe, hammer a nail, and use a circular saw,’ I email friends. 'In the snow.’

On that day, when Radcliffe crossed the finish line, the press gathered to understand her amazing run. Her time was so good that it would qualify her to compete in the men's marathon at the world championships in Paris. Journalists were curious about a natural treatment she used called emu oil, which Olympic gold medallist Cathy Freeman had recommended. Radcliffe used it to heal after she had an accident with a bike while training. Radcliffe says she never really understood how big her achievement was at the time. She felt it was just what she was meant to do that day. Her team had a motto: no limits.

During the race, her husband and coach, Gary Lough, was in a car with her support team, listening to the radio. Her physiotherapist, Gerard Hartmann, was also there. After 16 kilometers, Radcliffe's agent worried if she could keep up her fast pace, fearing she might have to stop. Hartmann was upset by this, but he understood why someone who didn't know her fitness level might think it was risky to start so fast.

With 800 meters left, Radcliffe realized she could finish in under 2 hours and 16 minutes if she ran the last part in less than three minutes. She had already run 41 kilometers very fast but still managed to sprint the last distance in 2 minutes and 25 seconds. At the finish, she thought, "I can run quicker than that." The race director, Dave Bedford, said he didn't think anyone would beat that time soon, but Radcliffe thought she could do it again next year. Unfortunately, that didn't happen.

After the race, people wondered how Radcliffe, with her awkward running style, beat the skilled East African runners. Hartmann had worked with her for weeks, helping her recover from running 250-300 kilometers each week. He said, "I've worked with 63 Olympic medallists, and no one could handle pain like her. She would push me to work so hard on her muscles that I had to ice my thumbs afterward."

Hartmann described traveling 13 hours from Ireland to Radcliffe's training base in France, only to be greeted by her husband saying, "Gerard, you're 15 minutes late, Paula's waiting." There was no time for a friendly chat; she was ready for a two-hour session. Radcliffe pushed him to give his best, which made her so good. During that time, Hartmann spent so much time with Radcliffe that his other athletes became jealous.

Can Radcliffe explain why no one has beaten her record? "Not really. I trained very hard, but there are more talented people out there. I thought Mary Keitany might do it. Maybe it's because people are racing each other more than racing themselves." What does she mean? "I never relaxed, even when I was winning. I always pushed myself as hard as I could."

Radcliffe didn't know it then, but that marathon was the peak of her career. She never ran as fast again, but she inspired many women to start long-distance running.

When my first cooking show, "In Search of Perfection," was released, I didn't know how people would react. At that time, there was a lot of talk about a food 'revolution' happening in Britain. I believed our show added something new to this movement, but I was still worried. Would people like a cooking show that included not just techniques, but also history, nostalgia, and science? I watched the first episode feeling both happy and scared. I didn't need to worry. The show was successful and led to many other interesting projects, including a book about my experiences at my restaurant. Each project feels like a journey, whether it's exploring the past, the mind, or cooking techniques. I then wrote several books in a series called "Perfection," each with its own TV show. In these, the journey was often very physical, involving travel with passports and suitcases. "In Search of Total Perfection" is the latest in the series. In it, you travel around the world to meet amazing people, like a man who makes the best-tasting golden pasta. These people have spent years trying to achieve their own idea of perfection. Perfection is very personal. Even choosing which dishes to include in the series was difficult, and I knew some people would be upset if their favorite dish was left out. I imagined people asking, "Where's steak and kidney pie and bread and butter pudding?" But after long discussions, the TV team and I created a list that had something for everyone. This showed me that everyone has their own idea of perfection, based on emotions, memories, and surroundings. Even though the book is called "Perfection," I knew I wasn't claiming the recipes were the best. But I thought that by using my skills and knowledge, and by talking to food experts, I could find out what made these dishes special. The dictionary says 'perfection' means being perfect, but it also means improving through constant experimentation. Trying ideas and changing them until you have something unique. The TV series allowed me to explore new foods, people, and places I hadn't seen before, and I was excited about that. Finding the best ingredients took me around the world. Some of my adventures included visiting a canning factory that processed the wrong tomatoes and a dairy farm with low standards where we couldn't film. To perfect each recipe, I ended up hand-milking a cow and using dry ice to make ice cream, cooking chicken breasts in a hospital scanner, and almost burning my house down trying to make a Neapolitan-style pizza.

We were still far from Marrakech when the van made a loud noise and suddenly went off the road into a field, stopping completely. John got out and opened the hood to look at the engine. He stood there for a long time, looking like he knew what he was doing. Finally, he admitted, "Actually, I have no idea what I'm doing," and he and Mum started laughing. Bea was worried and said, "We can't stay here forever." The field was huge, with just grass and lots of flowers like poppies and daisies. I agreed with Bea because it was usually best to be on her side. We got back into the van and waited for Mum and John to stop laughing. We watched John walk away to find someone who knew about cars. Mum lay down on the grass and asked me to tell a story. Bea lay next to her and said, "Go on, tell us a story." So, I told them about how I heard two birds talking the day before we left London. I told them what the birds talked about: breadcrumbs, other birds, the weather, and a fight over a worm. Bea said, "That's silly, no one understands bird language." My eyes hurt, and I said, "I do," but I didn't sound sure. "Liar," Bea said. I felt embarrassed. How could I be lying if I remembered everything? The more I thought about it, the less sure I was. "Mum...?" But she was asleep in the sun. John came back with three Moroccan boys who helped push the van to a hotel. Bea didn't want to get out, but the boys didn't mind. They waved and smiled at her through the back door windows. We followed John into a café near the road where our van was parked. "It's a hotel," John whispered. "It might be expensive." "We'll just have some tea," Mum said, and we sat in the shade. The tea was made from mint leaves and was very sweet. Mum looked into the pot and said, "It's like syrup in there." We stayed at the café all day while John tried to fix the engine. "It's a miracle it got us this far," he said as it got dark. Mum made a bed for us outside in the hotel garden. It was nice to sleep on ground that wasn't moving. "I'll have to get us towed into Marrakech," John said. Later, we were in a truck watching our van being towed with John driving it. At first, Bea didn't want to move, so John carried her into the truck. She sat in the front with the driver. I kept wondering how we would get home since our van needed to be towed. I thought it might be easier to take a boat straight to London. Then I fell asleep.

Lucy was at a welcome party in a hotel ballroom. She was talking to two other pianists who were playing at the Prague Classical Music Festival. They were not competing like her. One was a guy from Tokyo, and the other was a girl from a European city. Lucy didn't catch her name because of the noise, but it was something like Liesel or Louisa. They were both about ten years older than Lucy and spoke English well enough to discuss the music they were playing, their recent travels, and their future plans. 

Lucy mentioned, "I think I'm doing Tanglewood this summer." It sounded impressive, but she didn't really want to go. She didn't want to do many of the things that filled her time, like concerts and competitions. These events took her around the world and made her miss so much school that she wasn't officially enrolled anymore. Instead, she studied with tutors from the University of San Francisco. She hadn't even wanted to come to the Prague Festival, which only accepted fifteen pianists in her age group from around the world. Out of thousands of applicants, she was chosen. There was a party to celebrate. Her dad bought her a white-gold necklace with an L pendant, and her little brother Gus imagined himself at the same festival one day. Her teacher, Grace Chang, took her out for a special dinner to plan her music pieces. 

Lucy hadn't applied to the festival herself. Her mother had filled out the form and sent in the CD. Her mom said, "I didn't want you to be disappointed if you didn’t get in." Lucy thought it was more like her mom didn't want to give her the chance to say no. At that time, Lucy thought that causing trouble was the worst thing she could do, so she didn't even think about trying to get out of it.

The guy from Tokyo leaned forward, surprised. "Tanglewood?" he asked. "Yeah," Lucy replied. "How old are you?" he asked. "Fifteen," she said. He exchanged a look with Liesel/Louisa, who said, "Wow." Lucy didn't mean to show off. It was hard to know when she was just sharing information or bragging. "It's just part of this new youth-spotlight thing they're going to try..." she explained. 

Liesel/Louisa excused herself, looking across the room as if she saw someone she needed to talk to. The guy from Tokyo stayed and asked, "Have you ever been to Japan?" He had long, shaggy hair, like many musicians, to show they were cool music nerds. "Once. When I was, like, eight," Lucy replied. He started to say something when Lucy's grandfather appeared. "Lucy, let me introduce you to someone," he said, taking her arm and pulling her away. "And don't get too friendly with the competition." "They're not the competition," Lucy said. "Everyone is the competition," her grandfather replied. He took her around the room, making her talk to important people. Lucy smiled and nodded a lot, only hearing about half of what was said.

In the elevator to their suite after the party, her grandfather said, "You did well in there, Lucy. I’m proud of you. This is an important festival, and there’s a buzz about you. They all know who you are." Lucy liked that part. Being somebody. Even if some people were jealous or thought she was too young for the attention she got. Being a concert pianist didn't make her special to the kids she used to go to school with. Even her best friend, Reyna, didn't know or care that she could play a Rachmaninov allegro perfectly. But in places like this, she knew she mattered.

Dad said, "Spending too much time online isn't good for you. You need to experience the real world." It's hard to argue with him, so I looked into what experts say about this topic, and it's quite interesting. Research shows that most teenagers who use social media have many real-life friends, a strong sense of who they are, and are learning important technical skills for the digital age. Simon Miles, an e-safety expert, says social networking is a key part of growing up today. Teenagers don't just use media for tasks like buying tickets or checking emails like adults do; they live in it. It's not about whether it's good or bad, but how you use it.

Jim Matthews, a social media analyst, compares social networking to how today's parents used to hang out at youth clubs. It's like a virtual youth club where teenagers can develop their identity away from their parents and learn to handle teenage issues with their friends. Psychologist Professor Keith Davidson says that during adolescence, you ask yourself, "Who am I?" Social networking can help you find your identity by letting you share your favorite music or sports and see different perspectives. Research shows that active social networkers are less self-centered than those who don't use social media. He also says that social media can be helpful if you're shy because communicating online can be easier than face-to-face, allowing you to practice social skills in a less intimidating way.

Professor Andrew Phillips is studying how young people use social networking sites. He believes they can help quiet people with specific interests connect with others who share those interests. For example, if only a few people at your school like a certain type of music, you might feel alone. But if you find a social networking group with similar interests, you can feel popular in a different way.

Pauline White, a digital education expert, says teenagers who find new interests online, join groups of like-minded people, and create their own content are using social networks to their full potential. She thinks social networking is becoming a creative force, with teenagers making videos, podcasts, and blogs about their interests. Photo-sharing sites are changing creativity by allowing photographers to connect, learn, and share images. This can improve employability and be beneficial in the workplace. Every business uses social media to sell and increase brand awareness, so understanding how it works is important. For example, if you create a product and have 1000 friends on social networks, they could be potential customers. Linking these networks can build your customer base.

Matthews agrees that teenagers who use social networking creatively will benefit when they start working. Many sites offer opportunities to collaborate and share content, which is a valuable skill in the 21st century and important for being employable in a digital age.

When most people think of a relaxing family vacation, they probably don't imagine a long trip across nine western states in the US and a Canadian province. However, my parents had a different idea for our summer vacation this year. My dad decided to plan what many teenagers would consider a nightmare: a big family bonding trip. Before the trip, my parents kept saying, "Not enough people do this anymore," while my twin brother and I exchanged worried looks, thinking, "There's probably a good reason why!"

In mid-June, we packed our car with suitcases, coolers, and clothes for all kinds of weather. I was excited but knew I would miss my privacy for the next two weeks. I had some ideas on how to cope. With barely enough space left in the car, we started our "Family Great American Road Trip." As we left our comfortable home for smaller places to stay over the next five thousand miles, I wasn't the only one wondering what we were getting into.

We drove west through the Oklahoma panhandle. Even though we were still close to home, we had some adventures. We stopped for the night near a town in Oklahoma, under the darkest, star-filled skies, but only after almost being blown off the highway by a dust storm. We quickly learned that on the road, cattle have the right-of-way!

The next day, we got up at dawn and started driving again. I noticed a pattern forming. The desert turned into mountains. The days started to blend together, but each adventure was unique. We left our footprints in the Great Sand Dunes and moved on to Pagosa Springs, Colorado. The strong smell of sulfur in that friendly tourist town gave us a hint of what we would experience later. As we climbed to our next destination, we learned that roads marked for Jeeps are best left to Jeep drivers. Everywhere we stopped, we saw a mix of old and new. Dealing with construction traffic became normal. We laughed as we posed by the big "CLOSED" signs at the Four Corners Monument.

We passed many wind farms on our way to Yellowstone National Park, where we watched the sunset over bear habitats near the roads. "Bear jams," where traffic stops to let a bear cross, were common, and park volunteers managed them. Our own close encounter with a bear on the road, and an anxious park ranger, gave us unforgettable memories.

As we continued, life back home seemed far away, and even the old hotel we stayed in, with its problems, couldn't ruin our excitement. It was a 95-year-old building with no internet or cell phone service, but it offered the most amazing views I've ever seen. After watching a rainstorm from our cozy hotel in Canada, we headed back south. My parents were right. You don't need to go to an exotic foreign place to find something amazing. It was both happy and sad to be home again, but at least I hadn't fought with my brother during our one hundred hours on the road! We had three thousand photos from our crazy journey to look through and remember. For me, the best memories were the unplanned and spontaneous moments.

Rose Frost was sixteen years old and was going to live with her grandmother, Daisy. Rose's family was separating for two years because her father, Jeff, had a job overseas, and her mother, Dahlia, was going with him. Rose and her older sister, Amy, were staying in England. Amy would finish her last year of school, living under the care of the college Head. It was important for Amy to stay because it was her final year, and she was happy to have the best room at the college, with a kitchen and study area. She also had free Internet and phone access. Jeff and Dahlia would still be watching over Amy, even if she didn't like it.

Rose was moving to her grandmother's house. She only had vague holiday memories of her grandmother and never knew her grandfather. When Daisy offered Rose a place to stay, Rose's parents were not very excited, but Daisy insisted it was no problem and wanted to reconnect with her granddaughter. Rose didn't fully understand why her parents didn't get along with her grandmother, but there had been a disagreement in the past, so they spent holidays elsewhere. Rose was ten years old the last time she saw her grandmother, but her memories were happy. Dahlia said living with Daisy would be interesting because Daisy was very social and liked to bring people together. Rose expected to get dinner invitations, coffee morning requests, and shopping trips soon. This made Rose smile because her grandmother was not a typical old lady and seemed to attend more social events than the Queen of England.

Before moving, Dahlia and Rose had a talk. Rose was sensible and mature for her age. She knew about healthy eating, staying fit, and getting enough sleep. But Rose wanted her independence. She wanted to play music loudly, invite friends over, or go out without asking for permission every time. She didn't want to be nagged about homework or staying out late, and she didn't want to be dragged around by her grandmother. Daisy understood this. Rose's mother gave her a new touch-screen mobile phone with a video camera for emergencies only. Rose was very happy. They all agreed it would be about trust. Her grandmother would trust her to act maturely, and Rose would trust Daisy not to be too controlling. If either of them went too far, they would talk about it again.

Rose was never a wild child. Her few school friends were similar, so her school reports were always good, and her exam results were excellent. This helped her. In five weeks, Rose would start at a new school, meet new friends, and basically start her life again. It was her fourth senior school in five years, so she felt experienced at it now. At least she knew this was the last time because she would be starting her final two years at school. For Rose, it was a new beginning, a new piece in the puzzle of her life.

Charlotte Grainger shares that her primary school teacher was the first to suggest she might write a novel. She thought writing a book would be a great achievement because it seemed difficult, and she didn't know what other teenagers were doing, like participating in the Olympics. When she turned 13, she decided to try writing a novel. Now, that novel is about to be published. Charlotte recently told her former teacher about it, and the teacher was surprised. The teacher had thought Charlotte would write a book when she was 30 or 40. Charlotte never considered waiting that long because she wanted to try something she might be good at.

On a winter afternoon, in the offices of Charlotte's publishers, I was surprised to see a teenager there, even though I knew I was going to interview a 15-year-old about her book. The book is a big success: the story is confident and full of action. Nothing about it, except the age of its main character, suggests it was written by a teenager. A public relations representative is with us in case Charlotte needs help, but she doesn't need any support. She is confident, intelligent, and steady, which keeps her from being overconfident.

Charlotte admits that she is young and doesn't have all the answers. When I ask her about the complex moral issues in her book, she says, "I was trying to ask big questions, not answer them. I don't have many life lessons to share with my readers," she laughs. "I don't think my age limits my understanding of the world, but I also don't think I'm very wise. I was just interested in exploring the theme of taking responsibility."

Charlotte has a theory about how teenagers are portrayed in books. She believes there are three types of teenagers in novels: the outsider who becomes accepted, the naïve teenager who knows little about the world, and the awkward teenager who lacks social skills. Reading about these types annoyed her. "What if you're basically fine? There aren't many stories about characters who aren't flawed in some way. Some writers unintentionally suggest that teenagers can't know who they are because they lack experience, which can hurt their self-confidence."

Charlotte has always loved reading famous fantasy writers, but they almost discouraged her from writing. "Books by my favorite fantasy writers explore deep psychological and life issues. I wondered if I needed to do the same to write a good book and if I was capable of it." However, she praises a book called "How Not to Write a Novel" for teaching her that if readers can guess what will happen, the suspense is lost.

Some might think that Charlotte's parents, both journalists, helped her get her novel published. Her father's connection in publishing did help get her book read initially. She admits she was lucky because getting a first novel read is difficult, no matter the author's age. "Every aspiring writer needs support and a lucky break, but after that, you're on your own. Writers succeed or fail based on their talent, so I don't take things for granted," Charlotte concludes.

"‘Remember, speed is your friend, not your enemy,’ said Gareth, our instructor, as we looked down the ski slope. ‘Now, who wants to go first?’ The group looked nervous. Then David, who had some experience in freestyle ski-jumping and wanted to show he knew what he was doing, went first. He skied down the slope towards the jump. He went up the ramp quickly and flew into the air, waving his arms. Even we could see something was wrong. We held our breath. He hit the ground, lost both skis, and flipped head-first into the snow. ‘Remember,’ Gareth kindly told us, ‘speed is unpredictable.’ Maybe I wasn’t meant for this freestyle skiing. On past skiing holidays, I liked practicing turns in the snow. I wasn’t one of those teenagers doing tricks on ramps and half pipes in skateboard parks. I thought it looked fun, but I didn’t know how to do it, and I was afraid of being laughed at. Then my parents decided we’d have a winter holiday at a freestyle skiing training center in the US. It had a big indoor area near the slopes, with trampolines and ski jumps covered in fake snow. Students jumped and tried new tricks, landing in foam pits – not a real introduction to what we’d face on the slopes. After practicing indoors, students went outside to try for real. ‘Progression is inevitable!’ the center’s slogan said. ‘Before places like this trained people, inexperienced ski jumpers would just go down the slopes and hope for the best,’ said Gareth. ‘But remember – if you hit the knuckle, you’ll be in trouble.’ The ‘knuckle’ is the flat part behind the jump before the slope goes down again. Land in the right zone and you keep moving forward, reducing impact. Land on the flat and you stop suddenly, which hurts. That’s why you need speed. At first, it was hard to make my body ignore my brain and go fast towards the jump. My legs would almost go backward as I got close, so I landed on the knuckle. I didn’t fall, but by midday I felt shorter. ‘You need to control the jump, not let it control you,’ said Gareth. Day two started on the trampolines. I thought I’d hate being indoors, looking at the snowy peaks outside, but bouncing on the trampolines was fun. Some exercises copied ski-jumping moves, others taught ‘aerial awareness’ – knowing what your body is doing in the air. Gareth gave us feedback. My ‘aerial awareness’ needed work – every time I tried, I only remembered the moment before take-off, then found myself in the foam cubes. We went back to the mountain to try again. There were more setbacks before I finally landed properly. Gareth was as happy as I was, and for a few moments, I felt proud of achieving such a difficult goal. But that didn’t last long. On the last run of the day, I didn’t slow down as I approached the jump, went airborne, and landed correctly. Then I saw both skis sliding down the slope ahead, no longer on my feet."

Imagine you're on a rollercoaster at an amusement park. Your hands are sweaty with fear, and you hold tightly onto the safety harness. The ride stops suddenly, and you take a deep breath as the carriage slowly climbs up. There's a pause, then a sudden drop, and you feel your stomach lift. You speed forward, turn sharply left, and go upside down. Your senses are overwhelmed, and you scream from deep inside. But you chose this: like millions of others each year, you paid to enter the theme park.

It's interesting that amusement parks, with their exciting rides, are a big business. To create the thrills and escape from reality that visitors want, there are large teams of creative engineers and designers working behind the scenes. Being a 'rollercoaster designer' might sound like a child's dream job, but it's actually very challenging. Designers must create the right mix of fun and fear while keeping passengers safe. They also need to add new features to keep visitors coming back.

Many people think rollercoasters have become more intense over time, but most of the techniques used today were invented by John Miller, a US designer, in the early 20th century. Back then, rollercoasters were more extreme, but now designers are limited to the tracks made by specialist manufacturers.

I talked to three rollercoaster experts. Professor Brendan Walker, a 'thrill engineer,' said the skill is in putting the pieces together. Dr. John Roberts, from the Royal Academy of Engineering, explained that it's about quickly changing between different forces so people feel excited but safe. It's a fine line between thrilling and uncomfortable.

To create an amazing ride, teams must build a strong story, like a space adventure or a jungle chase, and combine it with new features like the tallest ride or the steepest drops. However, Professor Walker said that in the end, experience and trial-and-error are key. Jeff Hornick, a senior director of theme park development, agreed that designers need to love thrills to understand what passengers want and to test rides before they open to the public.

I asked if new technology, like virtual reality, will change rollercoaster design. Walker said not to expect too much. Virtual reality can add something extra, like painting an old rollercoaster, but the physical ride experience will still be the most important for many years.

At 25, Miranda Ellington has already done a lot as a choreographer, creating dances for many theatres and dance companies. She also still dances sometimes. I wonder why she does both activities with her busy schedule. She says, ‘Dancing again reminds me of what it’s like to be in the studio, taking orders from demanding choreographers, and how tense and frustrating that can be. Choreographers can forget what it’s like to rehearse all day.’ As a choreographer, she teaches and enjoys working with young students. ‘A new dancer is often open to exploring new ideas. In some ways, working with students is easier than with professionals because they’re willing to take risks. They want success but don’t fully know their strengths and weaknesses yet. This means they accept even harsh criticism. They might still question me sometimes, but I welcome their honest feedback.’

When Miranda starts with a new group, she focuses on the dance steps, and the music guides her. ‘There might be music I don’t like, but I still try to create the best dance routine for it. If dancers don’t respond well to a composer’s music, it can be frustrating, but I have to find solutions. I can’t just choose a new piece. I’d like to be more experimental and switch to different music – it would help when rehearsals get tough. But now I’m always working on big productions where the music is already decided by the composer and can’t be changed.’

Miranda doesn’t want to stay with one institution. ‘I think it’s important to keep meeting new people. But I have to remember that the theatres and schools I work with have different methods and styles. So I have to adapt each time I go somewhere new, instead of doing the same thing. This helps me avoid becoming too set in my ways.’

We talk about a recent documentary on ballet dancers and choreographers. ‘There have been glamorous documentaries before that were misleading,’ says Miranda. ‘This one tries to show what life is really like in a dance company. There was a scene where a young dancer gets many corrections, and I recognized that. She knows she’s not doing it right but can’t make her body do it. It’s hard to watch but not fake. The public doesn’t realize how much work and dedication ballet requires.’

I ask what makes a great ballet or dance production for Miranda. ‘It’s when everything – the music, costumes, lighting, and dancers – comes together. Perfection might be too much to ask for, but aiming high is appreciated by audiences and can make up for a few wrong choices. I’ve been in productions where the dance steps are great, but something about the costumes or props distracts. That’s disappointing.’

Miranda has done many different things, so I wonder how she sees herself: is she a modern dance choreographer or a ballet specialist? ‘People want to label you, and I don’t understand that. There’s also a trend to focus on one area, but I don’t follow that. Maybe one day I’ll be known for one thing, but for now, I want to explore different things.’

A friend once asked me why I travel when I can watch everything on TV. I agreed that TV shows amazing things, but why stay at home when there is so much to experience outside? That conversation gave me the idea for my unusual four-day trip and a film to encourage people to turn off their TVs. A friend of mine was getting rid of his old sofa, which became the main part of the film. I attached three wheels and some cables to it and used old seatbelts to secure myself. I put my luggage on the seats and slept on the sofa each night, even one night on the beach. Several friends joined me along the way, helping to pull the sofa and encouraging me to continue. I’ve been on several walking trips in recent years, but this was something completely new. It was not only the longest distance I have ever walked, but it was also on main roads. This meant I could stop at a roadside café and relax on the sofa with a cappuccino instead of having the wind blow away my sandwiches while sitting on a rock. I got used to telling people, “No, I’m not doing it for charity, and I’m not training for a marathon.” When someone at work asks me about my weekend, I’d rather explain how I dragged a sofa 100 miles across southern England than talk about the latest TV show. You can watch the film on my website.

When I read about guided swimming trips in the sea around some small Greek islands, I was excited. I had never tried organized group trips before. My brother, who I usually traveled with, was busy, so I thought a group holiday might be good for me. At the Greek port, the man seemed curious when I asked for a single ferry ticket because the islands are popular with families. I explained that I wouldn't be alone for long; I would be joining ten others to swim around the small islands. Although he still looked puzzled, he let me on board with a smile. Our group had exchanged emails before we started, but there was little time to talk before our first group swim. Our guides explained that a support boat would be with us the whole time and made sure we knew how to communicate with it. We did a short swim to divide us into speed groups, then it was time for our first real 1.5 km swim, and I was nervous. I had trained in my local pool and done some river swimming, but never long distances in the open sea. Soon, the waves got bigger, and I was at the back of the slow group - not where I wanted to be. I watched faster swimmers moving ahead like dolphins. I wanted to finish this first distance, and I was happy when I finally did it on my own. The following days had a routine: jumping in, reaching a comfortable speed, and stopping to admire the scenery. As the swims got longer, my speed and enjoyment also increased. We hardly needed the support boat. I can’t wait to come again next year.

Being a flight attendant isn't easy, but it's a great job for someone young like me. Since I started, I've traveled to many places, like the US and Australia. I work with amazing people, have a lot of free time, and life is never boring. 

When I was a child, I went to a boarding school abroad, so I often flew alone. I felt lonely and would ask the flight attendants if I could help give out meals to passengers, and some let me. This experience stayed with me when I wanted to leave my banking job and try something new.

At the interview for the flight attendant job, there were many young people, and many were accepted. They were often well-qualified and changing careers, like me. I practiced what to say before the interview. Instead of just saying I loved to travel, I talked about my strengths and past work experience, and I got the job!

I recommend this job to anyone because there are many good things about it. The free flights are nice, but they aren't the best part. Most airline staff work very hard, and there's a saying: "no-one’s finished till everyone’s finished." It's like a big family. Even though we don't see each other all the time, we're still close. When I'm not working, I don't have to take work home. If I do have difficult passengers, which doesn't happen often, I know the flight will end soon, and I probably won't see them again.

At the summer camp where I work, I love seeing the children succeed at things they never thought they could do. Almost all the children know how to swim and play table tennis before they come here, but rock climbing is new for most of them. Some children feel very nervous, but after some encouragement, they agree to try, and they all reach the top in the end. This makes them feel really good. Some children miss home at the start of the week. Surprisingly, it's not the very young ones who feel this way the most – it's actually the ten- to thirteen-year-olds. We don't let them use their mobile phones all the time. First, we tell them they can call home after lunch. Then, when they ask again, usually after dinner, we say it's a bit late to call now, do it tomorrow. Most children are fine after a couple of days, and at the end of their week, they all thank us because they had a great time. It's not always the children who feel lonely. Sometimes, parents call a lot, asking how their child is doing, which is not really necessary. Often, their son or daughter is busy playing games or doing something else, so we have to tell the parents to call back later. We often get a certain type of child coming, usually dressed in expensive new clothes. These children usually argue when we tell them to change into something more suitable, but soon they understand why.

'Rock the Planet' is a musical show where the actors also need to be great musicians. It started in London last year after being in the USA for five years, where it won 'Best Musical' four times! Doing the show with only British actors was difficult. In the UK, young actors can do fewer shows each week compared to the USA, so they needed twice as many actors in London. Fortunately, the director found many talented actors in the UK, and they have just won their first 'Best Musical' award. The London theatre is bigger than the one in the USA, and it has been full every night because everyone wants to hear the songs that were first popular in America.

I met Jamie, an 11-year-old actor in the show. He said, 'It's amazing that I get paid to play, especially on a beautiful and expensive Gibson guitar.' He explained how busy the young actors are. 'We have regular school lessons every day at the theatre. The teacher is great, but I miss my old school friends.' I asked what his friends think of the show. 'My whole class came! The theatre offers special ticket deals for schools. They loved it, and that made me feel really confident. My parents come when they can, but it's expensive for them,' he said.

When I told Jamie I also play guitar, he found an extra one and invited me to play with him and the other young actors. We played a song called 'Days,' which I didn't know. Jamie helped me learn it, and I was happy when I finally got it right. I was impressed by Jamie's talent and wished I had similar skills. I was just trying to keep up and was glad the show's director wasn't there to hear my mistakes!

The young actors were already musicians, and some played several instruments, but none had played in a band before. Luckily, they found it quite easy. Jamie said the hardest part was looking natural when they first performed together. They were concentrating so much that they forgot to smile! The show will be in London for another year, and it's definitely worth seeing.
